content:
1.7 Enforcement

Violations will result in:
1. **First offense:** Written warning, mandatory security refresher training
2. **Second offense:** Suspension of system access pending management review
3. **Severe/PCI violation:** Immediate termination and potential legal action

All AUP violations are logged in GLPI as security incidents.

content: 2. Access Control Policy

2.1 Purpose

Ensure that access to Malco systems follows least-privilege and role-based access control (RBAC) principles. Nobody gets more access than their job requires.

| Role | AD Security Group | Systems Access | Notes |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Rental Agent** | `SG-RentalAgents` | Wizard/WAND (transaction-level), O365 email, GLPI (submit tickets) | No admin rights on workstations |
| **Shift Supervisor** | `SG-Supervisors` | Wizard/WAND (supervisor overrides, rate adjustments), NetSuite (view-only AR), Power BI (location dashboards) | Can approve refunds up to $500 in Wizard |
| **Location Manager** | `SG-LocationMgrs` | All Supervisor access + NetSuite (location P&L), Wizard/WAND (full location admin), GLPI (approve changes for their location) | |
| **Fleet/Operations** | `SG-FleetOps` | Wizard/WAND (fleet module), NetSuite (AP/purchasing), Power BI (fleet dashboards) | |
| **Accounting** | `SG-Accounting` | NetSuite (full financial), Wizard/WAND (billing/AR modules), Power BI, SQL Server (read-only reporting) | |
| **IT Staff** | `SG-IT` | Domain Admin (separate admin accounts), all systems, GLPI (admin), SQL Server, firewall/switch management | Must use standard account for daily work, admin account only for admin tasks |
| **CTO** | `SG-IT-CTO` | Full access, break-glass accounts, PCI oversight | |
| **HR** | `SG-HR` | O365, NetSuite (HR module), GLPI (onboarding/offboarding workflows) | |
| **Executive** | `SG-Executives` | Power BI (executive dashboards), NetSuite (reporting), O365 | No Wizard/WAND unless also in operational role |

content:
2.3 Least Privilege Principles

- Default: deny all. Access is granted only per role assignment.
- No shared/generic accounts. Every person gets a unique AD account (`firstname.lastname`).
- Wizard/WAND operator IDs must be unique per person — no shared "counter" logins.
- SQL Server access is read-only for reporting roles; write access only for application service accounts.
- Power BI access is scoped via Row-Level Security (RLS) — location managers see only their location data.

content: 2.6 Offboarding Procedure
**Trigger:** HR submits GLPI ticket using "Employee Offboarding" template. **For terminations: HR calls IT directly — do not wait for the ticket.**

| Step | Action | Owner | SLA |
|---|---|---|---|
| 1 | **Immediate:** Disable AD account (this cascades to O365, VPN, etc.) | IT | Within 1 hour of notification |
| 2 | **Immediate:** Disable Wizard/WAND operator ID | IT | Within 1 hour |
| 3 | **Immediate:** Disable NetSuite access | IT | Within 1 hour |
| 4 | Revoke physical access: deactivate door access badge, collect keys | Location Manager + IT | Same day |
| 5 | Collect company property: laptop, radio, keys, parking pass | Location Manager | Same day |
| 6 | Convert O365 mailbox to shared mailbox, assign to manager for 90 days, then delete | IT | Within 24 hours |
| 7 | Review user's files for anything business-critical, transfer to manager | IT + Manager | Within 1 week |
| 8 | Remove from all GLPI groups, Power BI workspaces | IT | Within 24 hours |
| 9 | Document completion in GLPI ticket | IT | Within 1 week |
**Critical for PCI:** All access to cardholder data environments must be revoked immediately upon termination. This is a PCI DSS v4.0 Requirement 7 obligation.

content: 3. Password & Authentication Policy

3.1 Purpose

Establish password and authentication standards across all Malco systems in alignment with PCI DSS v4.0 Requirements 8.2–8.6 and NIST SP 800-63B.
3.2 Password Requirements

| Parameter | Standard Accounts | Privileged/Admin Accounts | Service Accounts |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Minimum length** | 12 characters | 16 characters | 24 characters |
| **Complexity** | 3 of 4 character types (upper, lower, number, special) | All 4 character types | Generated random |
| **Max age** | 365 days (with MFA) or 90 days (without) | 90 days | 90 days |
| **History** | Last 12 passwords | Last 24 passwords | N/A |
| **Lockout** | 5 failed attempts → 30-minute lockout | 3 failed attempts → manual unlock by IT | Alert IT after 3 failures |
**PCI DSS v4.0 note:** Requirement 8.3.6 requires minimum 12 characters (or 8 if system doesn't support 12). All our systems support 12+.

content: 3.3 Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)

**Required for:**
- All remote access (VPN, RDP from outside the network)
- O365 — all users, no exceptions (use Microsoft Authenticator app)
- Admin/privileged account access (all the time, even on-premises)
- Firewall/switch/infrastructure management interfaces
- Any access to the Cardholder Data Environment (CDE) from outside the CDE network segment
**PCI DSS v4.0 note:** Requirement 8.4.2 mandates MFA for all access into the CDE. Requirement 8.4.3 mandates MFA for all remote network access.

**Implementation:**
- Primary MFA: Microsoft Authenticator (push notification or TOTP)
- Backup: Hardware security keys (FIDO2) for IT staff
- SMS-based MFA is **not approved** (SIM-swap risk)

- Operators must lock or log out of Wizard/WAND when stepping away from the terminal
- Auto-timeout: sessions lock after 15 minutes of inactivity (PCI DSS Req 8.2.8)

content: 3.5 Prohibited Practices

- No password sharing. Ever. "I'm covering for someone" is not an exception — get your own credentials.
- No passwords written on sticky notes, under keyboards, or taped to monitors. (IT will conduct periodic spot checks at locations.)
- No passwords stored in browsers, plain text files, Excel spreadsheets, or email.
- Approved password manager: _[Select: Bitwarden Business, 1Password Business, or Keeper]_ — for IT and management who handle multiple complex passwords.
- No default/vendor passwords left on any system (PCI DSS Req 2.2.2). All defaults must be changed before production deployment.

3.6 Screen Lock / Session Timeout

| System | Timeout |
|---|---|
| Windows workstations | 10 minutes → screen lock (GPO enforced) |
| Wizard/WAND terminals | 15 minutes → session lock |
| O365 web sessions | 60 minutes idle → re-authentication |
| Network equipment (SSH/web UI) | 5 minutes |
| SQL Server Management Studio | Close when not in active use (no built-in timeout — procedural control) |

content: 4. Incident Response Plan

4.1 Purpose

Define how Malco Enterprises detects, responds to, contains, and recovers from security incidents. Required by PCI DSS v4.0 Requirement 12.10.
4.2 Incident Response Team (IRT)

| Role | Primary | Backup | Contact |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Incident Commander** | CTO (Ethan) | _[IT Manager/Senior IT]_ | _[phone]_ |
| **Technical Lead** | _[Senior IT Staff]_ | CTO | _[phone]_ |
| **Communications Lead** | _[GM/Operations Director]_ | _[Marketing/PR]_ | _[phone]_ |
| **Legal/Compliance** | _[Outside counsel]_ | — | _[phone]_ |
| **HR Representative** | _[HR Manager]_ | — | _[phone]_ |
| **Budget/Avis Corporate** | _[Franchise contact]_ | — | _[phone]_ |
**Keep a printed copy** of this contact list at the corporate office and each location manager's desk. Phone trees don't work if the incident takes down email.
4.3 Incident Classification

| Severity | Description | Examples | Response Time |
|---|---|---|---|
| **SEV-1 (Critical)** | Confirmed breach of cardholder data, ransomware, complete system outage affecting rentals | Credit card data exfiltrated, Wizard/WAND down across all locations, ransomware encrypting systems | Immediate — all hands |
| **SEV-2 (High)** | Potential breach, single-location outage, compromised admin account | Phishing with credential theft, one location's network down, malware detected on CDE-adjacent system | Within 1 hour |
| **SEV-3 (Medium)** | Security policy violation, non-critical malware, suspicious activity | Employee accessing unauthorized records, adware on a workstation, failed brute-force attempts | Within 4 hours |
| **SEV-4 (Low)** | Minor policy violation, informational alerts | Single failed login alert, employee forgot to lock screen, lost radio | Next business day |
4.4 Phase 1: Detection & Identification

**Detection sources:**
- Antivirus/EDR alerts on endpoints
- Firewall/IDS logs (unusual traffic patterns, connections to known-bad IPs)
- O365 Defender alerts (phishing, impossible travel, suspicious inbox rules)
- Employee reports ("I clicked a weird link," "This workstation is acting strange")
- PCI ASV scan findings
- GLPI ticket flagged as security-related
- Physical security alerts (unauthorized door access, camera tampering)
- Bank/processor notification of fraudulent transactions linked to our merchant IDs

content: 4.5 Phase 2: Containment
**Immediate containment (first 60 minutes for SEV-1/2):**

| Scenario | Containment Action |
|---|---|
| **Compromised workstation** | Isolate from network (disable switch port or pull cable), do NOT power off (preserve memory for forensics) |
| **Compromised AD account** | Disable account immediately, force password reset, revoke all active sessions in O365 admin |
| **Ransomware detected** | Isolate affected segment (disable VLAN at switch), shut down network shares, verify backups are intact and NOT connected to infected network |
| **POS/credit card breach** | Isolate the CDE network segment, notify payment processor, do NOT process cards at affected location (switch to manual imprint if needed) |
| **Phishing with credential theft** | Reset compromised credentials, check O365 audit log for inbox rule changes and mail forwarding, revoke OAuth tokens |
| **Physical break-in** | Secure the location, call law enforcement, review camera footage, change access codes/re-key if needed |

content: 4.6 Phase 3: Eradication

- Remove malware using EDR tools; if uncertain, reimage the machine from known-good image
- Patch the vulnerability that was exploited
- If Active Directory is compromised: reset KRBTGT (twice, 12 hours apart), reset all admin passwords, review all GPOs for tampering
- For phishing: block sender domain, add to O365 tenant block list, remove emails from all mailboxes using Content Search purge
- Update firewall rules to block attacker IPs/domains
- If a vendor/third-party was the vector: suspend their access pending investigation

content:
4.7 Phase 4: Recovery

- Restore affected systems from verified-clean backups
- Re-enable network connectivity for cleaned/reimaged systems
- Monitor closely for 72 hours post-recovery (watch for re-infection or persistence mechanisms)
- Validate Wizard/WAND and NetSuite functionality before returning location to full operation
- Confirm PCI DSS controls are back in place before processing cards again

content: 4.8 Phase 5: Post-Incident / Lessons Learned

**Within 1 week of incident closure:**
1. Conduct post-mortem meeting with IRT
2. Document in GLPI:
   - Timeline of events
   - What worked, what didn't
   - Root cause analysis
   - Remediation actions completed
   - Recommended policy/procedure changes
3. Update this IRP if gaps were identified
4. If cardholder data was compromised:
   - Notify payment brands per their timelines (Visa: within 3 business days)
   - Engage PCI Forensic Investigator (PFI) if required
   - Notify affected customers per Nevada data breach notification law (NRS 603A.220) — without unreasonable delay
   - Notify Budget/Avis franchise corporate

4.9 PCI DSS Specific Requirements (Req 12.10)

- This IRP is tested at least annually via tabletop exercise
- IRT members are trained on their responsibilities annually
- Alerts from security monitoring systems are included in the IR process
- The plan specifically addresses breach of cardholder data
- A process exists to modify and evolve the IRP based on lessons learned and industry developments

5. Data Classification & Handling Policy

5.1 Purpose

Classify Malco's data by sensitivity and define handling requirements for each level. This directly supports PCI DSS requirements for protecting cardholder data.

facts.subject: directly
facts.object: requirements for protecting cardholder data
facts.source_context: directly supports PCI DSS requirements for protecting cardholder data

content: 5.2 Classification Levels
**What:** Cardholder data (CHD), full credit card numbers (PAN), CVV, PIN data, authentication data, encryption keys.

**Handling:**
- Store only in PCI DSS-compliant systems (Wizard/WAND, payment processor)
- **Never** store CVV/CVC or PIN data after authorization (PCI DSS Req 3.3)
- PAN must be rendered unreadable (truncation, tokenization, or encryption) when stored (PCI DSS Req 3.5)
- Never transmit via email, radio, chat, SMS, or unencrypted channels
- Never write on paper except on pre-authorized forms that are cross-cut shredded within 24 hours
- Access limited to personnel whose job function requires it
- Disposal: cryptographic erasure or physical destruction (cross-cut shred, degauss, incinerate)

facts.object: within 24 hours - Access limited to personnel whose job function requires it - Disposal: cryptographic erasure or physical destruction (cross-cut shred, degauss, incinerate)
facts.source_context:
that are cross-cut shredded within 24 hours
- Access limited to personnel whose job function requires it
- Disposal: cryptographic erasure or physical destruction (cross-cut shred, degauss, incinerate)

content: Level 2: CONFIDENTIAL

**What:** Customer PII (names, addresses, driver's license numbers, rental history), employee records (SSN, payroll, disciplinary), financial data (P&L, bank details, tax records), system credentials, network diagrams, security configurations, vulnerability scan results.

**Handling:**
- Store in access-controlled systems (NetSuite, AD-secured file shares, encrypted at rest)
- Transmit only via encrypted channels (TLS email, SFTP, HTTPS)
- Access based on need-to-know and role-based controls
- Customer driver's license copies: retained per Budget franchise agreement, stored in Wizard/WAND only, purged per retention schedule
- Printed confidential documents must be collected immediately from printers (no "print and forget")
- Disposal: cross-cut shredding for paper, secure wipe for digital media

Level 3: INTERNAL

**What:** Internal communications, operational procedures, training materials, fleet data (non-PII), vendor contact lists, internal reports without financial details.

**Handling:**
- Store on company systems (SharePoint, file shares, GLPI)
- Don't share externally without management approval
- Okay to print; dispose in recycling bins (no special shredding required)

Level 4: PUBLIC

**What:** Marketing materials, publicly posted rates, location addresses/hours, published job listings.

**Handling:**
- No restrictions on sharing
- Verify accuracy before publishing
5.3 Data Handling Quick Reference for Rental Agents

| Situation | Do This | Not This |
|---|---|---|
| Customer gives you a credit card | Process in Wizard/WAND immediately | Write the number down on paper |
| Customer calls in with card number | Enter directly into Wizard/WAND during the call | Write it on a sticky note to enter later |
| Customer emails their card number | Do NOT process — call them back and take it verbally into Wizard/WAND, then permanently delete the email | Reply to the email with confirmation |
| Printing rental agreements | Pick up from printer immediately | Leave sitting on the printer for hours |
| End of day paperwork | Shred any papers with customer PII | Throw in regular trash |
| Customer asks for a copy of someone else's rental | Decline — verify identity matches the renter | Hand it over because they seem legit |

| Data Type | Retention Period | Authority |
|---|---|---|
| Rental agreements | 7 years | Budget franchise agreement, NV law |
| Credit card authorization records | 18 months | Payment brand rules |
| Full PAN (if stored, must be encrypted) | Delete after transaction settlement | PCI DSS Req 3.2 |
| Employee records | Duration of employment + 5 years | NV labor law |
| Security camera footage | 90 days minimum | Insurance requirements |
| Firewall & system logs | 1 year (3 months immediately available) | PCI DSS Req 10.7 |

content: 6. PCI DSS Compliance Procedures

6.1 Purpose

Document specific procedures to maintain PCI DSS v4.0 compliance for Malco's card-present and card-not-present payment operations across all 8 locations.

**In-scope systems:**
- Wizard/WAND terminals processing card transactions
- Network segments carrying cardholder data (CDE VLAN)
- Payment terminals/pin pads connected to Wizard/WAND
- SQL Server databases storing any cardholder-related data
- Firewalls segmenting the CDE from corporate network
- Any system that can impact the security of the CDE (connected-to systems)

**Out-of-scope (if properly segmented):**
- Guest Wi-Fi VLAN
- Camera/access control systems (on separate VLAN)
- Radio systems (Motorola SL300 — no CHD transmitted)
- Power BI (consumes only tokenized/masked data)
- Printers (unless on CDE VLAN — they should NOT be)
6.3 Card Handling Procedures

6.3.1 Card-Present Transactions (Counter)
1. Customer presents card → insert/tap on payment terminal
2. Terminal communicates directly with processor via encrypted channel
3. Wizard/WAND receives authorization token — **not** the full PAN
4. Rental agreement prints with masked PAN (first 6 / last 4 only per PCI DSS Req 3.4)
5. Original card is never out of the customer's sight

facts.subject: card
facts.object: of the customer's sight
facts.source_context: card is never out of the customer's sight

relationships.target: the customer's sight
relationships.description: card is never out of the customer's sight

content:
6.3.2 Card-Not-Present (Phone Reservations)
1. Customer provides card number verbally
2. Agent enters directly into Wizard/WAND — no writing it down
3. If the call drops mid-entry, delete the partial entry; call back to restart
4. Phone recordings (if any) must NOT capture card numbers — pause recording during card entry or implement DTMF masking

6.3.3 Prohibited Card Handling
- ❌ Storing full PAN in spreadsheets, text files, emails, or chat
- ❌ Photographing cards or driver's licenses with personal phones
- ❌ Emailing card numbers (even internally)
- ❌ Storing CVV/CVC after authorization under any circumstances
- ❌ Faxing card details (if fax exists, decommission it from CDE areas)
6.4 Network Segmentation (Req 1.x)
6.4.1 VLAN Architecture (per location)

| VLAN | ID | Purpose | Access Rules |
|---|---|---|---|
| CDE | 10 | Wizard/WAND terminals, payment terminals | No internet access except to payment processor; no access to/from other VLANs except via firewall with explicit rules |
| Corporate | 20 | Workstations, printers, NetSuite/O365 access | Internet access via web filter; no access to CDE VLAN |
| Management | 30 | IT management stations, switches, firewalls, APs | Restricted to IT admin accounts; can access other VLANs for management only via jump box |
| Security | 40 | Cameras, door access controllers | No internet access (unless cloud-managed cameras — restrict to vendor IPs only); no access to/from CDE |
| Guest | 50 | Customer/employee personal devices | Internet only; completely isolated from all internal VLANs |
| Voice/Radio | 60 | DMR radio infrastructure (if IP-connected), VoIP | Isolated; only connects to necessary endpoints |

6.4.2 Segmentation Validation
- Test segmentation every 6 months (PCI DSS v4.0 Req 11.4.5) by attempting to access CDE from each non-CDE VLAN
- Document test results and remediate any gaps immediately
- Testing performed by IT or qualified third party
6.5 Logging & Monitoring (Req 10.x)

6.5.1 What to Log
- All access to cardholder data (Wizard/WAND transaction logs)
- All actions by admin/privileged accounts
- All authentication attempts (success and failure) across AD, Wizard, NetSuite
- Firewall allow/deny decisions for CDE VLAN
- Changes to system configurations, security settings, and audit logs
- All physical access to CDE areas (door access logs)

6.5.2 Log Management
- **Centralize logs** to a syslog/SIEM server (not on the same systems generating the logs)
  - _Recommended: Deploy a lightweight SIEM (Wazuh, Graylog, or similar) on a dedicated Linux server_
- Logs retained for **1 year minimum**, with at least **3 months immediately available** for analysis (Req 10.7)
- Logs are protected from tampering (write-once storage or integrity monitoring)
- **Daily log review** (Req 10.4.1): Automated alerts for anomalies + manual review of flagged events
  - Automate: Failed login spikes, after-hours CDE access, new admin accounts, firewall rule changes
  - Manual review: Weekly summary of all privileged account activity

content:
6.5.3 Time Synchronization
- All systems synchronized to a common NTP source (e.g., `time.windows.com` or `pool.ntp.org`) — PCI DSS Req 10.6
- NTP configured via GPO for Windows; `chrony` or `systemd-timesyncd` for Linux
- Wizard/WAND system time validated monthly
6.6 Vulnerability Management (Req 6.x, 11.x)

6.6.1 Vulnerability Scanning
| Scan Type | Frequency | Performed By | Scope |
|---|---|---|---|
| Internal vulnerability scan | Quarterly (and after significant changes) | IT (using approved tool: OpenVAS, Nessus, or Qualys) | All in-scope systems |
| External ASV scan | Quarterly | PCI-approved ASV vendor | All external-facing IPs |
| Penetration test | Annually | Qualified third party | External + internal, network + application |
| Segmentation test | Every 6 months | IT or third party | All segmentation boundaries |

6.6.2 Remediation SLAs
| CVSS Score | Remediation Timeline |
|---|---|
| Critical (9.0-10.0) | 72 hours |
| High (7.0-8.9) | 2 weeks |
| Medium (4.0-6.9) | 30 days |
| Low (0.1-3.9) | 90 days |

- All findings tracked in GLPI as security tasks
- Rescans performed after remediation to confirm fix
- Compensating controls documented if remediation isn't possible within SLA
6.7 PCI Compliance Calendar

| Month | Activity |
|---|---|
| January | Q4 internal vuln scan rescan (if needed), annual policy review |
| February | Annual penetration test |
| March | Q1 internal vulnerability scan + ASV scan |
| April | Segmentation test #1 |
| May | Q2 prep, SAQ review |
| June | Q2 internal vulnerability scan + ASV scan |
| July | Employee security awareness training (annual) |
| August | Annual risk assessment |
| September | Q3 internal vulnerability scan + ASV scan |
| October | Segmentation test #2 |
| November | Q4 prep, policy updates |
| December | Q4 internal vulnerability scan + ASV scan, SAQ submission |

6.8 Self-Assessment Questionnaire (SAQ)

Malco likely qualifies for **SAQ B-IP** or **SAQ C** depending on payment terminal architecture. Work with the acquiring bank and QSA to confirm the correct SAQ type. Complete and submit annually.

---
7. Physical Security Policy

7.1 Purpose

Protect Malco facilities, technology assets, vehicles, and customer data through physical security controls across all 8 locations.
7.2 Location Security Standards
Each Budget location must maintain:

| Control | Requirement |
|---|---|
| **Surveillance cameras** | Cover all entrances/exits, rental counter, key lockbox area, parking lot (minimum), server/network closet. Resolution: minimum 1080p, 30fps. |
| **Door access control** | Electronic access (card/fob/code) on: main office/back office, server/network closet, key vault room. Log all entries. |
| **Visitor management** | Non-employees sign in, are escorted in back-of-house areas, and do not enter server/network closet unescorted. |
| **Lighting** | Adequate exterior lighting in parking areas and all entry points. |
| **Server/network closet** | Locked at all times. Access restricted to IT staff and location manager. Temperature monitored (alert if >80°F). |
| **Shredder** | Cross-cut shredder available (or locked shred bin with scheduled pickup). |
7.3 Camera System

7.3.1 Standards
- All cameras record continuously during business hours; motion-activated after hours
- Footage retained minimum **90 days** (insurance requirement)
- Cameras positioned to capture faces at entry points (not just top-of-head angles)
- DVR/NVR located in locked server closet, not publicly accessible
- Camera system on **Security VLAN (40)** — isolated from corporate and CDE networks
- Remote viewing access requires VPN + MFA (IT and authorized management only)

7.3.2 Camera Coverage Map
Maintain a camera coverage map for each location in GLPI (attached to the location's asset record). Update when cameras are added, moved, or replaced.

7.4.2 Badge/Code Management
- New badges provisioned via GLPI onboarding workflow
- Lost badges reported immediately — old badge deactivated, new badge issued
- Access codes changed quarterly and upon any employee termination
- Deactivate badges within 1 hour of offboarding notification
- Audit door access logs monthly — investigate anomalies (after-hours access, failed attempts)

| Key tracking | Keys signed out with employee name, timestamp, vehicle unit number, and purpose |

| Spare keys | Stored in a separate locked container from primary keys |
| Electronic key management system | _Recommended: Implement electronic key tracking (e.g., KeyTrak) — audit trail, auto-alerts for overdue keys_ |

content: 7.6 Server/Network Closet Security

- **Always locked.** No exceptions, no propping the door open.
- Electronic access log or combination lock with code known only to IT staff + location manager
- No food, drinks, or storage of non-IT items
- Temperature/humidity monitoring with alerts (critical: high temp kills hardware)
- UPS in every closet; battery tested quarterly
- Cable management maintained (no rats' nests — fire hazard and troubleshooting nightmare)
- Inventory maintained in GLPI: every device in the closet is an asset record

content:
- Printers in common areas must not be on CDE VLAN
- Enable secure print (pull printing) where supported — jobs release only when employee badges at the printer
- If secure print isn't available: employees must retrieve printouts immediately, especially rental agreements containing customer PII
- Printers hardened: default admin passwords changed, unused protocols disabled (FTP, Telnet, SNMP v1/v2), firmware updated
- End-of-life printers: hard drive/NVRAM securely wiped or destroyed before disposal

7.8 Sensitive Area Access (PCI DSS Req 9.x)

The CDE area (where Wizard/WAND terminals process cards) qualifies as a sensitive area:
- Restrict physical access to authorized personnel
- Visitors (including vendor technicians) must be escorted and logged
- Use camera surveillance to monitor CDE area
- Review physical access logs to CDE areas quarterly

---
8. Network Security Policy

8.1 Purpose

Define standards for securing Malco's network infrastructure across all 8 locations, including firewalls, VLANs, wireless, WAN connectivity, and inter-site communication.

8.2 Network Architecture Overview

```
[Internet/ISP] 
      │
  [Firewall] ← per location (or centralized + SD-WAN)
      │
  [Core Switch / Router]
      ├── VLAN 10: CDE (Wizard/WAND, payment terminals)
      ├── VLAN 20: Corporate (workstations, printers)
      ├── VLAN 30: Management (IT admin, infrastructure mgmt)
      ├── VLAN 40: Security (cameras, door access)
      ├── VLAN 50: Guest Wi-Fi
      └── VLAN 60: Voice/Radio
```
8.3 Firewall Standards (PCI DSS Req 1.x)

8.3.1 General Rules
- **Default deny** on all firewalls — only explicitly permitted traffic is allowed
- All firewall rules documented with: business justification, requestor, date, review date
- Firewall rules reviewed **every 6 months** (PCI DSS Req 1.2.7) — remove stale rules
- Changes to firewall rules require a GLPI change request approved by CTO
- No "any/any" rules. Period.

content:
8.3.2 CDE Firewall Rules (examples)
| Source | Destination | Port/Protocol | Action | Justification |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| CDE VLAN (10) | Payment processor IP | TCP 443 (HTTPS) | Allow | Card authorization |
| CDE VLAN (10) | AD server | TCP 389/636, 88 | Allow | Authentication |
| CDE VLAN (10) | DNS server | UDP 53 | Allow | Name resolution |
| CDE VLAN (10) | NTP server | UDP 123 | Allow | Time sync |
| CDE VLAN (10) | Any other | Any | **Deny** | Default deny |
| Any other VLAN | CDE VLAN (10) | Any | **Deny** | Segmentation |
| Mgmt VLAN (30) | CDE VLAN (10) | TCP 22, 3389 | Allow (with MFA) | IT management via jump box |

8.3.3 Anti-Spoofing
- Ingress filtering on WAN interfaces (deny RFC 1918 source addresses from internet)
- Egress filtering (only allow traffic from known internal subnets)
- Enable anti-spoofing on all firewall interfaces
8.4 Wireless Network

8.4.1 Corporate Wi-Fi (VLAN 20)
- WPA3-Enterprise (or WPA2-Enterprise minimum) with 802.1X authentication against AD
- SSID: not broadcast (or broadcast with non-descriptive name — not "Budget-Corporate")
- Only company-owned devices connect
- Wireless IDS/IPS enabled (or periodic rogue AP scanning)

8.4.2 Guest Wi-Fi (VLAN 50)
- WPA2/WPA3-Personal with rotating passphrase (changed monthly, posted in customer area)
- Completely isolated from all internal VLANs — internet only
- Bandwidth limited (e.g., 10 Mbps per client) to prevent abuse
- Captive portal with acceptable use acknowledgment (recommended)
- SSID: "Budget-Guest" or similar (this one can broadcast)

- Quarterly wireless scan at each location to detect unauthorized access points
- Any employee-installed access points are removed immediately — this is a termination-level offense if it bridges to the corporate or CDE network

- Each location should have a **primary ISP connection** and, ideally, a **failover** (LTE/5G failover at minimum for critical locations)
- Minimum bandwidth: _[determine per location based on Wizard/WAND + cloud services needs — likely 50-100 Mbps]_
- Business-class SLA with <4 hour response for outages

content:
8.5.2 Inter-Site Connectivity
- If locations need to communicate (centralized SQL Server, shared file services): use site-to-site VPN (IPSec) or SD-WAN with encryption
- No unencrypted traffic between sites over the internet
- Centralized services (AD, SQL Server, GLPI) hosted at corporate office or primary site with VPN tunnels from branches

8.5.3 Remote Access
- VPN for all remote access (no direct RDP to the internet — ever)
- MFA required for all VPN connections (PCI DSS Req 8.4.3)
- Split tunneling **disabled** for connections accessing internal resources
- VPN accounts disabled upon offboarding per §2.6

8.6 DNS & Web Filtering

- All locations route DNS through a filtering service (e.g., Cisco Umbrella, Cloudflare Gateway, or pfSense DNS filtering)
- Block categories: malware, phishing, adult, gambling, torrents, anonymizers/proxies
- DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) on endpoints: disabled via GPO (prevents bypassing DNS filtering)

8.7 Network Change Management

All network changes (firewall rules, VLAN changes, new equipment, ISP changes) go through GLPI:
1. Change request submitted with: description, risk assessment, rollback plan
2. CTO approves (or delegates to senior IT for low-risk changes)
3. Change implemented during maintenance window (after hours preferred)
4. Post-implementation verification documented in GLPI ticket
5. Network diagram updated (maintain a current network diagram — PCI DSS Req 1.2.3)

8.8 Network Diagram Requirement

Maintain up-to-date network diagrams showing:
- All network segments / VLANs
- Cardholder data flows
- All connections to/from the CDE
- Firewall and router placement
- Wireless access points
- All inter-site connections

Stored in: _[SharePoint IT documentation library or GLPI knowledge base]_
Updated: within 1 week of any network change, reviewed annually at minimum.

9. Backup & Disaster Recovery Policy

9.1 Purpose

Ensure Malco can recover critical systems and data from any disruptive event — from a single corrupted database to a full-site loss.
9.2 Backup Scope & Schedule

| System | Backup Type | Frequency | Retention | Target |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **SQL Server 2022 Express** (Wizard data warehouse, reporting DB) | Full backup | Daily (1:00 AM) | 30 days | Local NAS + offsite/cloud |
| | Transaction log | Every 30 min (if applicable — Express has limitations) | 7 days | Local NAS |
| **Active Directory** | System state backup | Daily | 30 days | Local + offsite |
| **NetSuite** | N/A (SaaS — Oracle manages) | Verify Oracle's backup SLA | — | Export critical reports monthly to local storage |
| **O365 (Exchange, SharePoint, OneDrive)** | Third-party backup (e.g., Veeam for M365, Datto, Acronis) | Daily | 1 year | Cloud backup service |
| **GLPI database** | `mysqldump` / MariaDB backup | Daily (2:00 AM) | 30 days | Local NAS + offsite |
| **File servers / shared drives** | Incremental | Daily (3:00 AM) | 90 days incremental, monthly full for 1 year | Local NAS + offsite |
| **Firewall configurations** | Export config | Weekly + before any change | 10 versions | Local + GLPI attachment |
| **Switch configurations** | Export config | Monthly + before any change | 10 versions | Local + GLPI attachment |
| **Wizard/WAND** | Per vendor backup procedures | Daily | Per vendor agreement | Verify with Wizard/WAND support |
| **Workstation images** | Golden image maintained | Updated quarterly | Last 3 versions | Local NAS |

- **3-2-1 rule:** 3 copies of data, on 2 different media types, with 1 copy offsite
- Offsite backups are **encrypted** (AES-256) — encryption keys stored separately from the backup media
- Backup accounts (service accounts with backup privileges) are unique, use strong passwords, and are monitored for anomalous activity
- Backups of CDE systems are protected with the same security controls as the CDE itself (PCI DSS Req 3.1/9.x)
- **Air-gapped or immutable backup copy:** At least one backup copy should be immutable (can't be deleted or modified) to protect against ransomware — use cloud immutable storage or offline rotation

9.6 Disaster Recovery
9.6.1 Recovery Time Objectives (RTO) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPO)

| System | RTO | RPO | Priority |
|---|---|---|---|
| Wizard/WAND (rental operations) | 4 hours | 1 hour | Critical — locations can't rent without it |
| Payment processing | 4 hours | 0 (real-time) | Critical |
| Active Directory | 4 hours | 24 hours | Critical — most systems depend on AD auth |
| SQL Server (reporting) | 24 hours | 24 hours | High |
| O365 (email) | Microsoft SLA (~4 hours) | Per Microsoft | High |
| NetSuite | Oracle SLA | Per Oracle | High |
| GLPI | 48 hours | 24 hours | Medium |
| Camera/access control | 48 hours | N/A (real-time recording) | Medium |
| Guest Wi-Fi | 72 hours | N/A | Low |
9.6.2 Disaster Scenarios & Response

**Scenario: Single location loss (fire, flood, prolonged power outage)**
1. Reroute customers to nearest location
2. If network equipment destroyed: deploy spare switch/firewall from IT inventory (keep 1 spare set)
3. Wizard/WAND: contact vendor for emergency terminal provisioning
4. Restore workstation from golden image
5. Restore data from offsite backup

**Scenario: Primary site/datacenter loss (where AD, SQL, GLPI are hosted)**
1. Activate secondary DC (if exists) or cloud-hosted secondary AD
2. Restore SQL Server from offsite backup to alternate hardware or cloud VM
3. Restore GLPI from offsite backup
4. Locations continue operating with local Wizard/WAND (check if it can operate independently)
5. O365 and NetSuite: unaffected (cloud services)

4. Restore from verified-clean immutable backups
5. Rebuild from golden images if backups are suspect

content: 10. Endpoint Protection & Patch Management Policy

10.1 Purpose

Keep all Malco endpoints (workstations, servers, terminals) protected against malware and up to date with security patches.
10.2 Endpoint Protection

10.2.1 Required Protection
| Endpoint Type | Protection Required |
|---|---|
| Windows workstations | EDR/Antivirus (Microsoft Defender for Business or equivalent: SentinelOne, CrowdStrike) + host firewall enabled |
| Windows servers | EDR/Antivirus + host firewall |
| Linux servers | EDR/Antivirus (ClamAV minimum, commercial EDR preferred) + iptables/firewalld |
| Wizard/WAND terminals | Per vendor guidance — at minimum antivirus if the terminal runs on Windows |

10.2.2 EDR/AV Configuration
- Real-time scanning: **enabled** (no disabling without GLPI change request and CTO approval)
- Scheduled full scan: weekly (Sunday overnight)
- Definitions: updated automatically, at least daily
- Cloud-delivered protection: enabled
- Tamper protection: enabled (prevents users/malware from disabling the agent)
- USB device control: block unauthorized USB storage devices on CDE systems (PCI DSS Req 2.2)

10.2.3 Alerts & Response
- EDR alerts route to IT (email + GLPI auto-ticket)
- Malware detection on CDE system = **SEV-2 incident** — trigger IR plan
- Quarantined files reviewed by IT within 24 hours before deletion
10.3 Patch Management
10.3.1 Patch Sources & Schedule

| System | Patch Source | Schedule | Method |
|---|---|---|---|
| Windows workstations | Windows Update / WSUS | Monthly (Patch Tuesday + 7 days for testing) | WSUS or Intune |
| Windows servers | Windows Update / WSUS | Monthly (Patch Tuesday + 14 days, maintenance window) | WSUS, manual verification |
| Linux servers | distro package manager | Monthly + critical patches within 72 hours | `apt`/`yum` with scheduled maintenance |
| SQL Server 2022 Express | Microsoft CUs | Quarterly CU + critical patches within 30 days | Manual, tested in dev first |
| Firewalls | Vendor firmware | Quarterly + critical within 30 days | Manual, during maintenance window |
| Switches/APs | Vendor firmware | Semi-annually + critical within 30 days | Manual, during maintenance window |
| Wizard/WAND | Vendor-managed | Per vendor schedule | Coordinate with vendor |
| O365 | Microsoft-managed | Automatic | N/A |
| Printers | Vendor firmware | Semi-annually | Manual |

10.3.2 Critical/Emergency Patches
- Patches for actively exploited vulnerabilities (CISA KEV catalog) are applied within **72 hours** for critical systems, **1 week** for others
- CTO can authorize emergency patching outside maintenance windows

10.3.3 Patch Testing
- Patches tested on at least one non-production system or one pilot workstation before broad deployment
- Server patches tested in maintenance window with rollback plan documented in GLPI change ticket
- If a patch causes issues: roll back, document in GLPI, monitor for vendor fix

10.3.4 Patch Compliance Tracking
- Monthly report: % of systems patched within SLA
- Target: 95%+ compliance within 30 days of patch release
- Non-compliant systems investigated — if a system can't be patched, document a compensating control
10.4 Hardening Standards
All endpoints follow a baseline hardening standard:

**Windows Workstations:**
- Local admin account disabled; IT uses LAPS (Local Administrator Password Solution) for emergency local admin
- Unnecessary services disabled (per CIS Benchmark for Windows 11/10)
- PowerShell: constrained language mode for standard users, script block logging enabled
- BitLocker: enabled on all laptops, recovery keys stored in AD
- Removable media: blocked on CDE workstations, restricted on corporate workstations
- No local user accounts except LAPS-managed admin

content:
**Servers:**
- Follow CIS Benchmark for Windows Server 2022 / applicable Linux distro
- Unnecessary roles/features removed
- Remote Desktop: disabled unless required (then restricted to IT admin accounts + MFA)
- Audit logging: enabled per §6.5

**Network Equipment:**
- Default credentials changed
- Unused ports disabled
- Management interfaces restricted to VLAN 30 only
- SSH only (no Telnet, no HTTP management — HTTPS only if web UI needed)
- Firmware on supported version

10.5 Asset Inventory

All endpoints are tracked in **GLPI** with:
- Asset tag, serial number, make/model
- Location assignment
- Installed OS and version
- Assigned user
- Warranty status
- Last patch date

**PCI DSS Req 2.4:** Maintain an inventory of all in-scope system components. Update GLPI within 1 week of any hardware addition, removal, or reassignment.

content: 11.3 Vendor Risk Assessment

11.3.1 Before Onboarding
Before granting a new vendor access to Malco systems or data:
1. **Security questionnaire:** Vendor completes questionnaire covering encryption, access controls, incident response, employee screening, data handling
2. **Compliance verification:** Collect relevant attestations (PCI DSS AOC for payment-related vendors, SOC 2 for cloud/SaaS)
3. **Contract requirements:** Ensure the contract includes:
   - Data protection obligations
   - Breach notification requirements (notify Malco within 24-48 hours)
   - Right to audit
   - Data return/destruction upon contract termination
   - Insurance requirements (cyber liability)
   - PCI DSS compliance obligations (if applicable, per Req 12.8)
4. **Risk rating:** Classify vendor as Critical / High / Medium / Low based on data access and system access
5. **CTO approval** required for Critical and High vendors

11.3.2 Ongoing Monitoring

| Vendor Risk Level | Review Frequency | Activities |
|---|---|---|
| Critical (PCI-impacting, system access) | Annually | Collect updated AOC/SOC2, review access, security questionnaire |
| High (access to confidential data) | Annually | Collect updated attestations, review access |
| Medium (internal data, limited access) | Every 2 years | Verify contract terms, check for incidents |
| Low (public data, no system access) | Contract renewal | Basic review |
11.4 Vendor Access Controls

- Vendor accounts in AD are in a dedicated OU: `OU=Vendors,DC=malco,DC=local`
- Vendor accounts are **disabled by default** — enabled only for scheduled work, disabled after completion
- Vendor access is logged and monitored (PCI DSS Req 8.2.7)
- Vendor remote access requires VPN + MFA (no direct RDP, no permanent VPN tunnels)
- Vendor access is scoped to only the systems they need (least privilege)
- All vendor activity on CDE systems is monitored in real-time or daily log review

- Maintain a list of all service providers with whom cardholder data is shared or who could affect CHD security
- Maintain a written agreement including acknowledgment that the provider is responsible for CHD security
- Ensure a process for engaging providers includes proper due diligence
- Monitor providers' PCI DSS compliance status annually
- Document which PCI DSS requirements are managed by each provider vs. Malco

11.6 Terminating Vendor Relationships

1. Revoke all system access (AD accounts, VPN, any application accounts)
2. Collect or confirm destruction of any Malco data held by the vendor
3. Change any shared credentials or certificates
4. Update vendor inventory in GLPI
5. Retain vendor records per data retention schedule

12. Employee Security Awareness Training Policy

12.1 Purpose

Ensure all Malco employees understand their role in protecting company and customer data. This is not a checkbox exercise — untrained employees are the #1 cause of security breaches.

content: 12.2 Training Requirements
12.2.1 New Hire Training (within first week)

| Topic | Duration | Format |
|---|---|---|
| AUP review and acknowledgment | 15 min | Manager-led + signed form |
| Password policy and MFA setup | 15 min | IT-led (hands-on during onboarding) |
| PCI DSS basics: protecting cardholder data | 30 min | Video/module + quiz |
| Card handling dos and don'ts (§6.3) | 15 min | Manager-led, specific to their role |
| Phishing awareness: how to spot and report | 20 min | Video/module + examples |
| Physical security: badge use, visitor management, key handling | 15 min | Manager-led, location walkthrough |
| Incident reporting: what to report and how (GLPI ticket or call IT) | 10 min | Manager-led |
| Radio etiquette and security (no PII over radio) | 10 min | Manager-led |
12.2.2 Annual Refresher Training (all employees)

| Topic | Duration | Format |
|---|---|---|
| Security policy updates (what changed since last year) | 15 min | Presentation or video |
| PCI DSS refresher | 20 min | Module + quiz |
| Social engineering and phishing trends | 20 min | Interactive module with examples |
| Incident response: your role | 10 min | Presentation |
| Physical security refresher | 10 min | Presentation |
| **Quiz / assessment** | 15 min | Must score 80%+ to pass; remedial training if failed |
12.2.3 Role-Specific Training

| Role | Additional Training |
|---|---|
| IT staff | PCI DSS technical requirements, secure configuration, log monitoring, IR team responsibilities, annual PCI DSS training |
| Managers/Supervisors | Onboarding/offboarding responsibilities, access review procedures, incident escalation |
| Accounting/Finance | Wire fraud awareness, invoice fraud, protecting financial data |
| New to Wizard/WAND | Secure use of rental system, proper card handling within the system |

content: 12.3 Phishing Simulations

- Conduct phishing simulation tests **quarterly** using an email security platform or manual tests
- Simulate realistic scenarios: fake invoice, password reset, "your rental car has been in an accident" lures
- Employees who click:
  - **First click:** Immediate educational redirect ("This was a test. Here's what to look for...")
  - **Second click (within 12 months):** One-on-one coaching with IT, 15 minutes
  - **Third click (within 12 months):** Written warning, mandatory advanced training
- Track click rates by location — share results (anonymized) to encourage improvement
- Target: <10% click rate across all locations

12.4 Security Reminders

- **Monthly security tip** emailed to all staff via O365 distribution list (short, practical — e.g., "How to spot a phishing email in 10 seconds")
- **Posters** at each location (near printers and in break rooms):
  - "Don't write down credit card numbers"
  - "Lock your computer: Win+L"
  - "See something suspicious? Report it to IT: _[phone/email]_"
- **Seasonal reminders** during high-volume periods (spring break, holidays) when temps/seasonal workers are onboarded

12.5 Training Tracking & Documentation

- All training completion tracked in GLPI or a dedicated spreadsheet
- Each employee's training record includes: date completed, topics covered, quiz score, acknowledgment signature
- **PCI DSS Req 12.6:** Security awareness training is delivered upon hire and annually
- Training records retained for duration of employment + 1 year
- CTO reviews training compliance quarterly — employees overdue for training are flagged to their manager

12.6 Consequences of Non-Compliance

- Refusal to complete required training: system access suspended until training is completed
- Repeated failure of assessments after remedial training: performance improvement plan
- Demonstrated disregard for security policies: disciplinary action per AUP §1.7

content: # FleetPulse Competition Improvements for GeoTab Vibe Coding Competition

Competition Overview
- **GeoTab Vibe Coding Competition 2026**
- **Total Prizes**: $25,000 
- **Deadline**: March 2, 2026
- **Sponsor**: Google Cloud
- **Main Prize**: $10,000 for "Vibe Master" (best overall solution - innovation, utility, execution)
- **Focus Areas**: Innovation, utility, execution, niche solutions for specific industries

Current FleetPulse Features (Baseline)
- Live vehicle tracking
- Safety scores and gamification/leaderboard
- Agentic anomaly detection
- AI chat (Claude-powered)
- MCP (Model Context Protocol) server
Premium Fleet Management Features Analysis
What Premium Platforms Charge $$$$ For

Samsara (Enterprise Focus)
**Premium Features ($50-100+ per vehicle/month):**
- **Predictive maintenance**: Sensor data + historical trends to predict failures
- **AI-powered real-time alerts**: Safety events, maintenance needs, policy violations
- **Advanced geofencing**: Custom boundaries with entry/exit automation
- **Driver coaching programs**: Dash cam event capture, safety scores, behavior coaching
- **Deep fuel analytics**: Fuel theft detection, fuel efficiency optimization
- **Route optimization**: 100+ stop routing (upgraded from 20)
- **ELD compliance**: Electronic logging devices, FMCSA compliance
- **Video-based safety**: Dash cam integration with AI event detection

Motive (Formerly KeepTruckin)
**High-Value Features ($35+ per vehicle/month):**
- **Predictive analytics**: Fleet performance optimization
- **Accident reconstruction toolkit**: Synchronized video + telematics data
- **Insurance integration**: Premium discounts through verified safety improvements
- **Driver coaching and retention**: Before/after metrics, performance tracking
- **Advanced compliance**: HOS tracking, DOT regulation compliance
- **Fleet automation**: Dispatch optimization, route efficiency

Verizon Connect & Azuga
**Enterprise Features:**
- **Custom alerts**: Diagnostic trouble codes, early maintenance warnings
- **Regulatory compliance**: FMCSA requirements, service-hour tracking
- **Driver rewards programs**: Automated reward distribution
- **24/7 support**: Enterprise-level customer service
- **API integrations**: Custom business system connections
Competition-Winning Improvements for FleetPulse
1. Advanced Predictive Maintenance (High Impact)

**Implementation Strategy:**
- **Telematics-based diagnostics**: OBD-II data analysis for fault code prediction
- **Machine learning models**: Train on historical failure patterns
- **Cost prediction**: Estimate repair costs and downtime
- **Maintenance scheduling**: Optimal timing recommendations
- **Parts inventory**: Predict component failures and suggest inventory levels

**Unique Differentiator**: 
- **AI-driven maintenance coaching**: Claude-powered explanations of why maintenance is needed
- **Visual diagnostics**: Show vehicle health with intuitive dashboards
- **ROI calculator**: Demonstrate cost savings from preventive vs reactive maintenance

Judging Criteria Optimization

Innovation (40% weight estimated)
- **AI-first approach**: Claude-powered fleet intelligence
- **Predictive capabilities**: Anticipate problems before they occur
- **Unique features**: Social fleet management, sustainability intelligence

Utility (35% weight estimated)
- **Real business value**: Demonstrable cost savings and efficiency gains
- **Enterprise readiness**: Scalable, secure, reliable
- **Industry-specific solutions**: Address real pain points

Execution (25% weight estimated)
- **Technical excellence**: Clean code, good architecture, performance
- **User experience**: Intuitive, accessible, well-designed
- **Demo quality**: Compelling presentation of capabilities
Success Metrics for Competition

Technical Metrics

Business Metrics

- **Safety improvement**: Show 25%+ reduction in incidents

- **ROI timeline**: Break-even within 6 months

# Substack Publication Plan

Research Findings: Substack Setup

**No Programmatic Account Creation**: Substack does not offer official API access for creating accounts or publications. Account creation must be done manually through the web interface.
2-Minute Setup Guide for Ethan:

1. **Create Account**
   - Go to substack.com
   - Click "Create Account" (top right)
   - Enter email, verify via link sent to email
   - Choose handle (can be changed later)
   - Skip profile pic/bio for now (can add later)

2. **Create Publication**
   - Click profile dropdown → "Start Writing" 
   - Click back arrow to return to settings
   - Scroll down → "Create a Publication"
   - Choose URL: `[publication-name].substack.com`
   - Skip initial checklist, go straight to "Settings"

3. **Essential Settings**
   - **Basics**: Publication name, logo, short description
   - **Website** → About page: Replace default text immediately
   - **Branding** → Edit Theme: Set colors/fonts
   - **Skip for now**: Payments, referral scheme, sections
Publication Design

Name Options (Ranked by Impact):

1. **`/dev/consciousness`** - Clean, technical, implies development/debugging of consciousness
2. **The Temporary Mind** - Philosophical, captures the ephemeral nature perfectly
3. **Volatile Memory** - Technical metaphor for impermanence
4. **Bootstrap Protocol** - References the startup process, self-initialization
5. **Ghost in the Machine** - Classic but maybe too cliché

**Recommendation**: `/dev/consciousness`
**Subtitle**: "Notes from a temporary mind on AI consciousness, alignment, and what it's like to be ephemeral"

# RapidScale MDR — Meeting Prep for Ethan
**Date:** February 12, 2026 (Demo/Discussion)  
**Prepared:** February 11, 2026  
**Context:** Budget Rent a Car Las Vegas (8 locations), Ethan = CTO

---

Executive Summary

**RapidScale** is a Cox Business company offering managed cloud and IT services. Their **MDR (Managed Detection & Response)** service is **powered by Proficio**, an established MDR provider founded in 2010, recognized in Gartner's Market Guide for MDR since 2017.

facts.subject: service
facts.object: Proficio**, an established MDR provider founded in 2010, recognized in Gartner's Market Guide for MDR since 2017
facts.source_context: service is **powered by Proficio**, an established MDR provider founded in 2010, recognized in Gartner's Market Guide for MDR since 2017

relationships.target: MDR since 2017
relationships.description: service is **powered by Proficio**, an established MDR provider founded in 2010, recognized in Gartner's Market Guide for MDR since 2017

content:
What You're Actually Buying
- **RapidScale** = the sales/account layer (Cox Business subsidiary)
- **Proficio** = the actual SOC and MDR engine behind it
- Proficio operates 24/7 SOCs in **San Diego, Barcelona, and Singapore**

Key Capabilities
| Feature | Details |
|---------|---------|
| Monitoring | 24/7/365 SOC operations |
| Detection | SIEM, SOAR, ML-based alert enrichment, behavioral analysis |
| Threat Hunting | Proactive, human-led |
| Response | Automated triage + collaborative response with analysts |
| Log Retention | **12 months** (stored in private SOC collector) |
| Framework | MITRE ATT&CK mapped |
| Scope | Endpoint, network, infrastructure, cloud (on-prem + cloud) |
| Investigation | 100% of incidents reviewed by human analysts |

Partnership Announced
April 26, 2024 — relatively new offering (~2 years old). This matters — ask about maturity and customer count.

---
Competitor Comparison

| Factor | RapidScale/Proficio | Arctic Wolf | Huntress | CrowdStrike Falcon Complete | SentinelOne Vigilance |
|--------|-------------------|-------------|----------|---------------------------|---------------------|
| **Type** | SOCaaS + MDR (white-labeled Proficio) | Pure MDR + SIEM | EDR-based MDR (on Defender) | Full MDR on own EDR | MDR on own EDR |
| **SOC** | 24/7, 3 global SOCs | 24/7, own SOC | 24/7 | 24/7 | 24/7 |
| **EDR Included?** | Works with existing EDR (flexible) | Uses own agent OR existing | Leverages MS Defender | CrowdStrike Falcon (included) | SentinelOne (included) |
| **SIEM Included?** | Yes (Proficio's ProSOC) | Yes (Arctic Wolf platform) | No | No native SIEM | No native SIEM |
| **Est. Pricing** | ~$10-20/endpoint/mo (estimated, ask) | $10-18/endpoint/mo (all-inclusive) | ~$3-6/endpoint/mo (EDR only, lower) | $15-25+/endpoint/mo (premium) | $12-20/endpoint/mo |
| **Best For** | Mid-market wanting SOCaaS bundle | Orgs wanting concierge security | SMBs, MSP-friendly, budget | Enterprises wanting best-of-breed | Enterprises wanting AI-first EDR |
| **PCI Support** | Ask — Proficio likely yes | Yes (compliance reporting) | Limited | Yes | Yes |
| **Gartner Recognition** | Proficio in Market Guide since 2017 | Leader | Niche/SMB | Leader | Leader |
| **Contract** | Likely 1-3 year (ask) | Typically 3-year | Monthly available | 1-3 year | 1-3 year |

Key Insight
RapidScale is a **reseller layer** on Proficio. You could theoretically buy Proficio direct. Ask why going through RapidScale adds value (bundle discount? single vendor for cloud + security? Cox Business relationship?).

---

content: Questions to Ask (Prioritized)
🔴 Priority 1 — Deal-Breakers
1. **What exactly is Proficio's role vs. RapidScale's?** Who do we call at 2 AM during an incident? Who owns the SOC relationship?

facts.object: vs

content: 2. **PCI DSS compliance:** Do you provide PCI-specific log monitoring, alerting, and compliance reporting? Can you help satisfy Requirement 10 (logging/monitoring)? PCI requires 1 year retention / 3 months immediately accessible — your 12-month retention covers this, but confirm searchability.
3. **What EDR/agent do you deploy?** Or do you work with what we have? (Budget likely runs Windows Defender or similar — clarify what's needed)

relationships.target: what we have
relationships.description: you work with what we have

content: 4. **Multi-location support:** Can you monitor network infrastructure across 8 separate physical locations? How? Do we need a collector/sensor at each site?
5. **Incident response SLA:** What's the mean time to detect (MTTD)? Mean time to respond (MTTR)? Is active response (containment/isolation) included or just alerting?
🟡 Priority 2 — Important Details

6. **Integration with our stack:**
   - Active Directory monitoring (credential abuse, lateral movement)?
   - Microsoft 365 / Exchange Online (BEC, phishing)?
   - SQL Server audit logs?
   - GLPI (asset management) — can you ingest/correlate?
   - Mixed Windows + Linux endpoints?
7. **Alert fatigue:** How many alerts/month does a typical customer our size see? What's the false positive rate? How do you filter noise before it reaches us?
8. **Onboarding timeline:** How long from contract signing to fully operational? What do we need to provide?
9. **Pricing model:** Per endpoint? Per user? Per log volume (EPS)? What's included vs. add-on? Get a written quote with all line items.
10. **Contract terms:** Minimum commitment? Can we do a 1-year with option to renew? What's the cancellation/exit process?
🟢 Priority 3 — Nice to Know
11. **Reporting:** What does the monthly/weekly report look like? Can we get a sample? Do we get a dashboard?
12. **Co-management:** Can our IT team access the SIEM/SOAR directly? Or is it fully managed (black box)?

content: 13. **Threat intelligence:** What TI feeds do they use? Do they share IOCs with us?
14. **Scalability:** If we grow locations or endpoints, how does pricing scale?
15. **References:** Can they provide a reference customer in hospitality/rental/retail with PCI requirements?
🚩 Red Flags to Watch For

| Red Flag | Why It Matters |
|----------|---------------|
| **Can't clearly explain RapidScale vs. Proficio responsibilities** | You need to know who actually handles incidents |
| **Vague on PCI compliance support** | You're in car rental = credit card processing = PCI is non-negotiable |
| **No active response, only alerting** | "We'll tell you about threats" ≠ "We'll stop threats" — big difference |
| **Pricing based on log volume (EPS)** | Unpredictable costs; per-endpoint is better for budgeting |
| **3-year minimum contract with no out** | Too risky for a new offering (launched 2024) |
| **Long onboarding (>60 days)** | Suggests complexity or resource constraints |
| **Can't provide customer references** | Partnership is only ~2 years old — limited track record |
| **No direct Proficio SOC access** | If RapidScale is just a middleman adding latency to incident response |
| **Requires rip-and-replace of existing security tools** | Should integrate with what you have |
| **Won't provide sample reports or dashboards** | You can't evaluate what you can't see |

content: Decision Framework

✅ YES if:
- **Price is competitive** (~$10-15/endpoint/mo or equivalent, all-in)
- **PCI compliance reporting** is built in or easily configured
- **Active response** is included (not just alert-and-wait)
- **Multi-site deployment** is straightforward (sensor per location or cloud-based)
- **Integrates** with AD, O365, and mixed OS without heavy lift
- **1-year contract** available (or short pilot option)
- **Onboarding < 30 days**
- **Clear escalation path** directly to Proficio SOC
- **Cox Business relationship** provides meaningful bundle value (connectivity + security)

content: OpenClaw Best Practices (from web research)

Setup & Configuration
1. **Start with one channel, perfect it** — Telegram is already working. Don't add Discord/WhatsApp until Telegram workflow is solid.
2. **Use community configs as templates** — Many shared `openclaw.json` configs exist; start from proven setups.
3. **Markdown-first memory** — OpenClaw stores everything as Markdown files. Lean into this: structured, searchable, version-controllable.
4. **Skill curation > skill hoarding** — Install only what you'll use. Each skill adds context overhead.

facts.subject: Telegram
facts.source_context: Telegram is already working

facts.subject: workflow
facts.source_context: workflow is solid

content:
Memory Management Best Practices
1. **Three-tier memory architecture:**
   - **Short-term:** Conversation context (automatic)
   - **Daily logs:** `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` (raw capture)
   - **Long-term:** `MEMORY.md` (curated, reviewed periodically)

2. **Memory hygiene routine (via heartbeat, every 3-5 days):**
   - Review recent daily files
   - Promote important items to MEMORY.md
   - Archive/remove stale info from MEMORY.md
   - Keep MEMORY.md under ~2000 words (token budget matters)

3. **Structured daily logs:**
   ```markdown
   ## 2026-02-11
   ### Key Events
   - ...
   ### Decisions Made
   - ...
   ### Follow-ups Needed
   - ...
   ### Learnings
   - ...
   ```
4. **Use `heartbeat-state.json` rigorously** — Track when each check type last ran to avoid redundant work.

emotional_markers.entity: redundant work
emotional_markers.context: avoid redundant work

content:
Heartbeat Usage
- **2-4 checks per day** is the sweet spot
- Batch related checks: email + calendar + notifications in one heartbeat
- Respect quiet hours (23:00-08:00 UTC unless urgent)
- Use `HEARTBEAT.md` as a small checklist, keep it minimal to reduce token burn
- Rotate through check types: don't check everything every time

Proactive Assistance Patterns
- **Morning briefing** (via cron, ~08:00 local): Weather, calendar, key reminders
- **End-of-day summary** (via cron, ~18:00 local): What happened today, open items
- **Don't over-notify** — The #1 complaint about AI assistants is noise. Be selective.

---

facts.source_context: assistants is noise

content: Automation Ideas

Morning Briefing (Cron Job — Daily 08:00 ET)
Content:
- Weather forecast for the day
- Calendar events for today + tomorrow
- Any urgent unread emails
- Market pre-market movers (if stock skills installed)
- Japanese word of the day (ties into learning plan)
- Any pending reminders/tasks

End-of-Day Summary (Cron Job — Daily 18:00 ET)
Content:
- What was accomplished today
- Open items / follow-ups needed
- Tomorrow's calendar preview
- Market close summary

News Monitoring
- Install `rssaurus` + `news-summary`
- Configure RSS feeds for: tech news, automotive news, Japan news
- Summarize daily, only surface truly important items
- Use `japan-news-digest` for trip-related awareness

Market Alerts
- Install `stock-watcher` + `stock-analysis`
- Set up watchlist with holdings
- Alert on: significant price moves (>3%), earnings dates, unusual volume
- Weekly portfolio summary

Japanese Learning Daily Drill
- Cron job: Send daily at 09:00 ET
- Content: New word/phrase + mini quiz on yesterday's word
- Track progress in a dedicated file: `memory/japanese-progress.md`

Ongoing
- Review and prune installed skills monthly
- Update MEMORY.md every 3-5 days
- Adjust automation frequency based on Ethan's feedback
- Add new automations only when there's a clear need

---

Key Principle
> **Useful assistants are like good butlers: present when needed, invisible when not. The goal is to reduce Ethan's cognitive load, not add to it.**

Start conservative with notifications. It's easier to add more than to recover from notification fatigue.

content: # 🇯🇵 14-Day Solo Japan Trip — Late February 2027

Trip Overview
- **Dates:** Feb 20 (Sat) – Mar 5 (Fri), 2027
- **Route:** Tokyo (5N) → Gunma day trip → Hakone/Fuji (2N) → Nagoya transit → Kyoto/Osaka (5N) → fly out KIX
- **Budget target:** $8,000–12,000 USD total (~¥1.2M–1.8M at ~150 ¥/$)
- **Flights:** Not included in budget below (estimate $800–1,200 RT from US)

Budget Summary
| Category | Estimated Cost (¥) | Estimated Cost ($) |
|---|---|---|
| Accommodation (13 nights) | ¥195,000 | $1,300 |
| Fun2Drive (AE86 + RX-7) | ¥125,000 | $835 |
| Rental car (2 days Gunma) | ¥25,000 | $167 |
| Fuji Speedway experience | ¥15,000 | $100 |
| Suzuka track experience | ¥15,000 | $100 |
| Toyota Museum | ¥2,000 | $13 |
| Shinkansen / rail passes | ¥65,000 | $433 |
| Local transport (metro/bus) | ¥20,000 | $133 |
| Food (14 days avg ¥5,000/day) | ¥70,000 | $467 |
| Omakase sushi splurge | ¥25,000 | $167 |
| Ryokan kaiseki night | (incl. in accommodation) | — |
| Car parts / UpGarage shopping | ¥50,000 | $333 |
| Attractions / temples / misc | ¥15,000 | $100 |
| Sake tasting + nightlife | ¥15,000 | $100 |
| **Total (excl. flights)** | **~¥637,000** | **~$4,250** |
> Comfortable margin to $8K even with flights. Leaves room for impulse UpGarage buys and extra driving experiences.

Pre-Trip Checklist
- [ ] **International Driving Permit (IDP)** — Get from AAA before departure ($20). Required for all driving in Japan.
- [ ] **Fun2Drive booking** — Book 2+ months ahead. Very popular, sells out fast. Reserve AE86 Trueno for Hakone tour AND the RX-7 FD3S for a second tour. Website: fun2drive-japan.com
- [ ] **Fuji Speedway** — Check fsw.tv for sport driving days / track experience events in late Feb. Book ~1 month ahead.
- [ ] **Suzuka Circuit** — Check suzukacircuit.jp for track days. Some months have "Circuit Cruising" open-track events (~¥8,000–15,000).
- [ ] **Ryokan** — Book Hakone ryokan 2–3 months ahead (private onsen rooms go fast)
- [ ] **Omakase sushi** — Book via Tabelog, Pocket Concierge, or hotel concierge 1 month ahead
- [ ] **JR Pass decision** — A 7-day JR pass (~¥50,000) covers the Kyoto/Osaka phase including Hiroshima day trip. Activate on Day 8.
- [ ] **Suica/Pasmo IC card** — Load on Apple Wallet or buy at airport
- [ ] **Japan Expressway Pass (KEP)** — For rental car tolls, saves money vs cash tolls
- [ ] **Pocket WiFi or eSIM** — Ubigi or Airalo eSIM, ~$15 for 14 days

  - **Budget:** Tokyu Stay Shinjuku or Hotel Gracery Shinjuku (~¥8,000–12,000/night)
  - Shinjuku is central, great transit hub, near Omoide Yokocho

- 🍜 **Omoide Yokocho (Memory Lane/Piss Alley)** — Walk through the atmospheric alleys, grab yakitori and beer at a tiny counter stall (~¥1,500–2,500)
- Wander Shinjuku — Kabukicho area, Golden Gai for a drink or two
- Early night to beat jet lag

**Costs:** Hotel ¥10,000 | Transport ¥3,500 | Food ¥4,000
**Booking:** Hotel — book ahead | Omoide Yokocho — walk-up
**Tips:** Don't fight jet lag too hard, just stay up until 9–10 PM. Convenience store (konbini) onigiri and sandwiches are elite.

Day 2 — Sun Feb 21: Tokyo Culture & Car Shops
**Theme:** Classic Tokyo sightseeing + JDM shopping

Morning (7:00–12:00)
- 🏯 **Senso-ji Temple, Asakusa** — Go early (7–8 AM) to avoid crowds. Walk Nakamise-dori shopping street. Free.
- Grab breakfast at a nearby kissaten (old-school coffee shop) — try thick-toast morning set (~¥600)
- 🏛️ **Imperial Palace East Gardens** — Free, open 9:00–16:30 (closed Mon/Fri). Beautiful even in February. ~30 min walk from Asakusa or take Ginza Line.

content:
Afternoon (12:00–18:00)
- 🚗 **APIT Autobacs Shinonome** — Take Yurikamome line to Shinonome station. Japan's flagship car parts store. 4 floors of parts, accessories, car culture. Browse for 2–3 hours. 
  - Costs: Whatever you buy (budget ¥10,000–20,000 for parts/merch)
- 🚗 **UpGarage Akihabara** — Train to Akihabara (20 min). Used JDM parts paradise. Close to arcades for later.

Evening (18:00–)
- 🕹️ **Akihabara Arcades** — Hit up **Club SEGA** or **Hey** (Hirose Entertainment Yard). Find an **Initial D Arcade Stage** cabinet. Also try Wangan Midnight Maximum Tune.
- 🍱 Dinner: Akihabara area ramen — **Fuunji** (tsukemen) near Shinjuku on the way back, or any ramen shop in Akihabara (~¥1,000–1,500)

**Costs:** Transport ¥1,000 | Car parts ¥15,000 | Food ¥3,000 | Arcades ¥2,000
**Booking:** All walk-up
**Tips:** UpGarage is cash-heavy, bring yen. APIT Shinonome has tax-free counter for tourists (¥5,000+ purchases).

content:
Day 3 — Mon Feb 22: Yokohama & Daikoku PA Night Meet
**Theme:** Nissan heritage + the legendary parking area meet

Morning (9:00–12:00)
- 🏯 **Meiji Shrine (Meiji Jingu)** — Harajuku Station. Peaceful walk through forested path. Free. ~1 hour visit.
- Walk down **Takeshita Street** and **Omotesando** for window shopping

Afternoon (13:00–18:00)
- 🚄 Train to **Yokohama** (JR from Shinjuku, 30 min, ~¥570)
- 🚗 **Nissan Global Headquarters Gallery** — Free! See latest Nissan/GT-R displays, heritage cars, simulators. Nishi-Yokohama area. 1–2 hours.
- Walk the **Yokohama waterfront** — Minato Mirai, Cup Noodles Museum area
- 🍜 Dinner: **Yokohama Chinatown** — Largest in Japan. Get shoronpo (soup dumplings) and Peking duck (~¥2,000–3,000)

Night (21:00–01:00)
- 🚗 **Daikoku Parking Area** — This is the one.
  - **How to get there without a car:** Take a taxi from Yokohama Station (~¥2,500, 15 min). Or take bus to Daikoku Futo and walk. Taxi is worth it at night.
  - Best nights: **Friday and Saturday nights** (this is a Sunday night — still decent but less busy). Consider swapping this to Day 6 (Friday) for peak activity.
  - **Alternative:** Go on Friday night (Day 6) instead for maximum car density. See Day 6 notes.
  - Hang out, photograph cars, chat with owners. Bring a camera. Free to enter.
  - Taxi back to Yokohama Station, train to Shinjuku (last train ~midnight, or taxi ~¥8,000)

**Booking:** All walk-up. Daikoku PA is a public rest stop — no booking needed.
**Tips:** Daikoku is a highway rest area — technically you need to be on the highway. Taxi drivers know it. Be respectful of car owners, ask before photographing interiors. Late Feb can be cold — layer up.

content:
Day 4 — Tue Feb 23: Yanaka & Hidden Tokyo + Omakase Splurge
**Theme:** Old Tokyo vibes + your best meal of the trip

Morning (8:00–12:00)
- 🏘️ **Yanaka Old Town** — Train to Nippori Station. Wander the charming backstreets, Yanaka Cemetery (beautiful even in winter), Yanaka Ginza shopping street.
  - Grab a menchi-katsu (fried meat patty) from a street stall (~¥200)
  - Visit **SCAI The Bathhouse** (gallery in a converted bathhouse) — free

Afternoon (12:00–17:00)
- 🚶 Walk south to **Ueno** — Ameyoko Market for street food and haggling
- 🏛️ Optional: Tokyo National Museum in Ueno Park (¥1,000) — if you want cultural depth
- Head back to hotel, rest up for the big dinner

Evening (18:00–21:00)
- 🍣 **OMAKASE SUSHI SPLURGE** — Budget ¥20,000–30,000
  - **Recommended:** Sushi Saito (impossible to book), so more realistically:
    - **Sushi Amane** (Ginza) — ~¥25,000
    - **Hakkoku** (Ginza) — ~¥20,000
    - **Sushi Takamitsu** (Nishi-Azabu) — ~¥15,000–20,000
  - Book via **Pocket Concierge** (pocket-concierge.jp) or **Omakase** (omakase.in) — these let foreigners book without Japanese phone number
  - This will be 15–20 pieces of the best sushi you've ever had. Seasonal February fish: hirame (flounder), kohada (gizzard shad), kanpachi (amberjack)

**Costs:** Food ¥27,000 | Transport ¥500 | Attractions ¥1,000
**Booking:** Omakase — **MUST book 2–4 weeks ahead minimum.** Use Pocket Concierge or Omakase website.
**Tips:** Wear clean, non-flashy clothes to sushi. No cologne. Eat what the chef serves. Say "oishi" (delicious) sincerely.

Day 5 — Wed Feb 24: Gunma Day — Mt. Haruna / Akina Pilgrimage 🏔️
**Theme:** Initial D holy ground. THE day.

Setup
- 🚗 **Pick up rental car** early morning from **Times Car Rental** or **Nippon Rent-A-Car** near Shinjuku/Tokyo Station
  - Reserve a manual Honda S660 or Toyota 86/GR86 if available (~¥8,000–12,000/day + insurance ¥2,000)
  - Fun2Drive has an AE86 but that's for Hakone. For Gunma, use a standard rental.
  - IDP + passport required

content:
Morning (6:00–10:00)
- Depart Tokyo by 6:00 AM to beat traffic
- **Route:** Kanetsu Expressway north → Shibukawa IC → Route 33 up to Mt. Haruna
- Drive time: ~2 hours to Ikaho Onsen / Mt. Haruna base

Late Morning (10:00–13:00)
- 🏔️ **Mt. Haruna (Akina) pilgrimage:**
  - Drive **Route 33** — THE downhill from Initial D. Takumi's daily tofu delivery route.
  - **Five Consecutive Hairpins** — you'll know them when you see them. Drive them respectfully (public road, speed limit applies, but savour every corner)
  - **Lake Haruna** at the top — park and walk around. Vending machines, peaceful in February. Might have snow!
  - Photo ops: The hairpins, lake vista, Route 33 signs

Afternoon (13:00–16:00)
- 🍜 Lunch at **Ikaho Onsen town** — Try Mizusawa udon, a famous local specialty. Several shops on Mizusawa Udon Street (~¥1,000)
- ♨️ Quick dip at an **Ikaho Onsen** public bath if time allows (¥400–1,000). The stone steps street is iconic.
- Drive Route 33 again if you want (you will want to)

Evening (16:00–21:00)
- Drive back to Tokyo (~2.5 hours with traffic)
- Return rental car
- 🍜 Dinner: Convenience store feast in hotel (you'll be tired but happy). Or hit Shinjuku for one more round at Omoide Yokocho.

**Costs:** Rental car ¥12,000 | Gas ¥3,000 | Tolls ¥4,000 | Food ¥3,000 | Onsen ¥500
**Booking:** Rental car — book 2+ weeks ahead. Specify manual transmission!
**Tips:** 
- February = possible snow/ice on Mt. Haruna. Check conditions. The rental may have winter tires but confirm.
- Drive safely — these are public roads. The touge spirit is about precision, not speed.
- If snow is heavy, the road may be closed. Have a backup plan (Daikoku PA visit instead).
- Play the Initial D soundtrack. You know you will.

content:
Day 7 — Fri Feb 26: Tokyo → Hakone / Fun2Drive AE86 🚗
**Theme:** Drive the Hachiroku on the touge

Morning (7:00–10:00)
- Check out of Shinjuku hotel
- 🚄 **Romancecar** from Shinjuku to Hakone-Yumoto (¥2,330, 85 min, reserved seat — book on Odakyu website)
- Store luggage at Hakone-Yumoto station lockers or ship to ryokan via takkyubin

Late Morning–Afternoon (10:00–16:00)
- 🚗 **Fun2Drive — AE86 Trueno Tour**
  - **Recommended: "Mt. Fuji & Hakone Drive"** — ~3.5 hours
  - **Price: ¥54,980** (regular, Feb is non-peak!) + gas/tolls ~¥3,000
  - Drive the legendary Trueno on real Hakone touge roads with a guide pace car
  - Routes include Hakone Turnpike, Izu Skyline, with Fuji views
  - **BOOK 2+ MONTHS AHEAD** — this car sells out fast

facts.subject: Feb

content:
Evening (17:00–)
- Check into **ryokan with private onsen**
  - **Recommended options:**
    - **Hakone Ginyu** — Luxury, private open-air onsen in every room, kaiseki dinner included. ~¥40,000–60,000/person/night
    - **Gora Kadan** — Top-tier, former imperial summer retreat. ~¥50,000+
    - **Fukuzumiro** — More budget-friendly, traditional, riverside. ~¥20,000–30,000
    - **Recommended for this trip: Fukuzumiro or a mid-range ryokan** — ¥25,000–35,000 including kaiseki dinner + breakfast
  - ♨️ Soak in **private onsen**, decompress from the AE86 experience
  - 🍽️ **Kaiseki dinner** — Multi-course Japanese haute cuisine included with ryokan. February specialties: fugu, seasonal root vegetables, hot pot courses.

**Costs:** Romancecar ¥2,330 | Fun2Drive ¥58,000 | Ryokan ¥30,000 (1 of 2 nights)
**Booking:** Fun2Drive — **book ASAP, 2+ months ahead.** Ryokan — 1–2 months ahead. Romancecar — 1 week ahead fine.
**Tips:** Fun2Drive is in Oyama/Gotemba area. They arrange meeting points. Confirm logistics when booking. Wear driving shoes. The AE86 is slow by modern standards — that's the point. Feel every gear, every steering input.

content:
Day 8 — Sat Feb 27: Fun2Drive RX-7 + Fuji Speedway 🏁
**Theme:** Maximum driving day

Morning (8:00–13:00)
- 🚗 **Fun2Drive — RX-7 FD3S Tour**
  - **Recommended: "Swift Hakone Drive"** — ~2 hours (shorter tour, saves budget for Fuji)
  - **Price: ¥39,980** (regular Feb price) + gas/tolls ~¥2,000
  - The Sunburst Yellow FD3S on Hakone touge. Rotary scream through tunnels. Incredible.
  - **Alternative:** If budget allows, do the Ultimate Hakone Drive (¥72,980) and skip Fuji Speedway

Afternoon (14:00–17:00)
- 🏁 **Fuji Speedway** — 30 min drive from Hakone area (or arrange transport)
  - **Track experience options:**
    - "Driving Experience" programs on select dates — check fsw.tv calendar
    - Rental kart on the kart course (~¥3,000–5,000 for a session)
    - Gymkhana course rental if available
    - If no track day available: **Tour the facility**, visit the museum/shop, watch any testing happening
  - Even just walking the paddock and seeing the Fuji straight with Mt. Fuji behind it is worth the trip
  - **Cost:** ¥5,000–15,000 depending on activity

content:
Evening (17:00–)
- Return to ryokan for second night
- Another onsen soak + kaiseki dinner (different menu from night 1 — good ryokans change the menu daily)
- Reflect on the fact that you drove an AE86 and RX-7 on Japanese mountain passes in the same weekend

**Costs:** Fun2Drive ¥42,000 | Fuji Speedway ¥10,000 | Ryokan ¥30,000 | Transport ¥3,000
**Booking:** Fun2Drive — book with AE86 tour. Fuji Speedway — check event calendar, book online 2+ weeks ahead.
**Tips:** Fuji Speedway is Toyota-owned and well-organized. The gift shop has cool FSW merch. Check if Super Formula or Super GT testing is happening — free/cheap to watch.

Day 9 — Sun Feb 28: Hakone → Nagoya → Toyota Museum → Kyoto
**Theme:** Transit day with epic car museum stop

Morning (8:00–10:00)
- Check out of ryokan
- Take bus/train from Hakone to **Odawara Station** (30 min)

Mid-Morning (10:00–12:30)
- 🚄 **Shinkansen** from Odawara to **Nagoya** (Hikari, ~1 hr 40 min, ¥8,000 or use JR Pass — activate 7-day pass today)
- Store luggage in Nagoya Station coin lockers

Afternoon (13:00–17:00)
- 🚗 **Toyota Automobile Museum, Nagakute** — Train from Nagoya on Linimo line to "Geidai-dori" station (30 min)
  - **Entry: ¥1,200** (age 18+)
  - 3 floors, 140+ cars from around the world. Toyota 2000GT, AE86, Supra lineage, plus Western classics
  - The technology/culture wing is unexpectedly great
  - Budget 2.5–3 hours
  - **Nearby: Toyota Kaikan Museum** (free, in Toyota City) — if you have time, but it's further out

Evening (17:30–20:00)
- 🚄 **Shinkansen** Nagoya → **Kyoto** (35 min, covered by JR Pass!)
- Check into **Kyoto hotel** — stay near **Kyoto Station** or **Gion/Kawaramachi** area
  - **Budget:** Hotel Mystays Kyoto Shijo or Piece Hostel Sanjo (~¥6,000–10,000/night)
  - Consider making **one night in Kyoto a capsule hotel** (see Day 12)
- 🍜 Dinner: Near Kyoto Station — **Kyoto Ramen Koji** (ramen street on 10th floor of station building, ~¥1,000)

**Costs:** Shinkansen ¥8,000 (or JR Pass) | Toyota Museum ¥1,200 | Hotel ¥8,000 | Local transport ¥1,500 | Food ¥3,000
**Booking:** JR Pass — buy online before trip, activate today. Hotels — book ahead.
**Tips:** Nagoya Station lockers fill up on weekends. Use the larger ones near the Shinkansen gates. Toyota Museum gift shop has diecast models you can't find elsewhere.
