content:
Day 10 — Mon Mar 1: Kyoto Temples Day
**Theme:** The classic Kyoto circuit

Morning (6:30–12:00)
- ⛩️ **Fushimi Inari Taisha** — GO AT SUNRISE (6:30 AM). The thousand torii gates are magical with no crowds. Free.
  - Hike to the summit (2–3 hours round trip) or just the iconic tunnel section (30 min)
  - JR Nara Line from Kyoto Station to Inari Station (5 min, ¥150)
- 🍵 Breakfast: Grab matcha and a pastry at a café near Inari

facts.subject: gates
facts.object: no crowds
facts.source_context: gates are magical with no crowds

content:
Afternoon (12:00–17:00)
- 🏯 **Kinkaku-ji (Golden Pavilion)** — Bus 205 from Kyoto Station (30 min). ¥500 entry. Stunning even in Feb — possible snow on the gold!
- 🏯 **Nijo Castle** — Bus or subway. ¥1,300 entry. Nightingale floors, shogun history. ~1 hour.
- 🏯 **Kiyomizu-dera** — Bus to Gojozaka. ¥400 entry. The wooden terrace overlooking Kyoto. Walk Ninenzaka and Sannenzaka lanes downhill for shopping/snacks.

Evening (17:00–21:00)
- 🏮 **Gion District** — Walk from Kiyomizu area. Watch for geiko (geisha) on Hanamikoji street around 5–6 PM as they walk to appointments.
- 🍽️ Dinner: **Pontocho Alley** — narrow alley of restaurants along the Kamogawa river. Pick any place that looks good.
  - Try **obanzai** (Kyoto home-style cooking) — ~¥2,000–3,000
  - Or splurge on **Kyoto kaiseki** at a more casual spot

**Costs:** Transport ¥1,500 | Temples ¥2,200 | Food ¥4,000
**Booking:** All walk-up. No reservations needed for temples.
**Tips:** Kyoto bus day pass ¥700 covers unlimited rides. February is LOW season — way fewer tourists than spring/fall. If it snows, Kinkaku-ji in snow is one of the most photographed scenes in Japan.

content:
Day 11 — Tue Mar 2: Arashiyama + Nara Day Trip
**Theme:** Bamboo, deer, and giant Buddha

Morning (8:00–12:00)
- 🎋 **Arashiyama Bamboo Grove** — JR Saga-Arashiyama Station. Go EARLY (8 AM) for empty paths.
  - Walk to **Tenryu-ji Temple** garden (¥500) — stunning
  - Cross the **Togetsukyo Bridge** — iconic mountain backdrop
  - Monkey Park Iwatayama (¥550) — hilltop park with wild monkeys and panoramic views
- 🍡 Snack: Arashiyama matcha soft serve and rice crackers from street vendors

Afternoon (13:00–18:00)
- 🚄 Train to **Nara** (JR Nara Line from Kyoto, 45 min, ¥720, covered by JR Pass)
- 🦌 **Nara Park** — Free-roaming deer! Buy shika senbei (deer crackers, ¥200) and get mobbed.
- 🏛️ **Todai-ji Temple** — World's largest wooden building housing a giant bronze Buddha. ¥600 entry. Absolutely awe-inspiring.
- ⛩️ **Kasuga Taisha Shrine** — Thousands of stone lanterns in a forest path. ¥500 for inner shrine. Mystical atmosphere.

Evening (18:00–)
- Train back to Kyoto
- 🍶 **Fushimi sake district** — Kyoto's sake brewery area. Visit **Gekkeikan Okura Sake Museum** (¥600, includes tastings) or bar-hop the local sake bars.
- Dinner: Izakaya near your hotel — try Kyoto specialties like yudofu (hot tofu) and nishin soba (herring buckwheat noodles) (~¥2,500)

emotional_markers.entity: yudofu (hot tofu) and nishin soba (herring buckwheat noodles) (~¥2,500)

content:
**Costs:** Transport ¥2,000 | Temples/attractions ¥2,500 | Food ¥3,500 | Sake tasting ¥2,000
**Booking:** All walk-up
**Tips:** Nara deer bow if you bow to them (sometimes). Hold crackers above your head — they go feral. Protect your map/paper goods.

Day 12 — Wed Mar 3: Himeji Castle + Capsule Hotel Night
**Theme:** Japan's most beautiful castle + unique accommodation

Morning–Afternoon (8:00–15:00)
- 🚄 **Shinkansen** Kyoto → **Himeji** (45 min, JR Pass)
- 🏯 **Himeji Castle** — 15 min walk from station. ¥1,050 entry.
  - Japan's finest surviving castle. Pristine white, UNESCO World Heritage. Budget 2–3 hours to explore all floors and gardens.
  - **Koko-en Garden** next door (¥310, or combo ticket ¥1,050) — beautiful traditional garden
- 🍜 Lunch: **Himeji oden** (local specialty) or anago (conger eel) near the station (~¥1,500)

Afternoon (15:00–18:00)
- Train back to **Osaka** (Shinkansen to Shin-Osaka, 30 min, JR Pass)
- Check into **CAPSULE HOTEL** in Osaka for the experience! 🛏️
  - **Recommended:** 
    - **Nine Hours Shinsaibashi** — Sleek, minimalist, ¥4,000–5,000/night
    - **First Cabin** — More spacious capsules, ¥4,500–6,000
    - **Capsule Hotel Asahi Plaza** — Budget classic, ¥3,000–4,000
  - Store big luggage in station locker (capsules have tiny lockers)

facts.subject: capsules
facts.source_context: capsules have tiny lockers)

content:
Evening (18:00–)
- 🏮 **Dotonbori, Osaka** — THE street food capital
  - **Must-eat:** Takoyaki (octopus balls) — ¥500 at Wanaka or Kukuru
  - **Must-eat:** Okonomiyaki — Mizuno or Chibo (~¥1,000–1,500)
  - **Must-eat:** Kushikatsu (deep-fried skewers) — Daruma (~¥1,500)
  - **Must-eat:** Gyoza from Chao Chao
  - Walk Dotonbori canal, Glico Running Man sign, neon madness
  - 🍺 Hit **Hozenji Yokocho** (tiny atmospheric alley) for a nightcap

**Costs:** Transport (JR Pass) | Himeji ¥1,360 | Capsule ¥4,500 | Food ¥5,000
**Booking:** Capsule hotel — book online 1 week ahead. Himeji — walk-up.
**Tips:** Capsule etiquette: no phone calls, no alarms blaring, be quiet after 10 PM. Use the communal onsen bath — it's great. Earplugs help with snorers.

Day 13 — Thu Mar 4: Suzuka Circuit + Osaka Evening
**Theme:** F1 holy ground + Osaka nightlife

Morning (7:00–13:00)
- 🚄 Early train Osaka → **Suzuka** (JR to Nagoya, then transfer to Kintetsu Line to Shiroko Station, ~2.5 hrs total)
  - Or limited express options — budget ¥4,000–6,000 one way
- 🏁 **Suzuka Circuit**
  - **Track experience options:**
    - **Circuit Cruising** — Open track days where you drive your own/rental car. Check schedule.
    - **Racing Kart** — Available most days, ¥3,000–8,000 per session on a real Suzuka sub-track
    - **Amusement park** — Has racing-themed rides including a racing coaster that runs on the circuit
    - **Pit Walk / Facility Tour** — Sometimes available on event days
  - Even without track time: Walk the paddock, visit the **Suzuka Circuit Museum/Shop**, see the 130R and Spoon corners
  - Check suzukacircuit.jp/eng for February 2027 events

Afternoon (14:00–18:00)
- Train back to Osaka (~2.5 hrs)
- Check into regular Osaka hotel near **Namba/Shinsaibashi** (¥8,000–10,000)
  - Or stay in same Kyoto hotel and commute (50 min each way) — Osaka is close

Evening (19:00–)
- 🍶 **Sake tasting in Osaka**
  - **Sake Bar Masu** (Umeda) — Great selection, English menu
  - **Ajinoya** — Sake paired with Osaka food
- 🍜 More Dotonbori exploring if you didn't get enough yesterday
- **Shinsekai district** — Retro Osaka, tsutenkaku tower area, more kushikatsu, game arcades with a gritty charm

**Costs:** Transport ¥10,000 | Suzuka ¥8,000 | Hotel ¥9,000 | Food ¥4,000 | Sake ¥3,000
**Booking:** Suzuka karts — book online if possible. Hotel — book ahead.
**Tips:** Suzuka is remote — the train journey is part of the experience. If no track events are scheduled for your dates, consider skipping and spending extra time in Osaka. The racing karts alone are worth the trip though.

**Theme:** History, floating torii, and farewell

> ⚠️ This is an ambitious final day. Alternative: Do Hiroshima on Day 12, Himeji on Day 13, and have a relaxed final day.

Early Morning (6:00–8:30)
- 🚄 **Shinkansen** Osaka/Kyoto → **Hiroshima** (Nozomi ~1.5 hrs from Shin-Osaka, but Nozomi not covered by JR Pass; use Hikari/Sakura ~2 hrs)

Morning (8:30–11:00)
- ☮️ **Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park & Museum** — ¥200 entry. Profoundly moving. Budget 1.5–2 hours.
  - See the A-Bomb Dome (exterior, UNESCO site), Children's Peace Monument, and the museum

Midday (11:00–14:00)
- 🚢 **Miyajima Island** — JR train to Miyajima-guchi (25 min) + ferry (10 min, covered by JR Pass)
  - ⛩️ **Itsukushima Shrine** — The floating torii gate. ¥300 entry. Iconic.
  - 🦌 More deer! (Miyajima deer are bolder than Nara's)
  - 🍁 Try **momiji manju** (maple leaf-shaped cake) — the island's specialty
  - If time: Hike up Mt. Misen for panoramic views (ropeway ¥1,100 one way)

Afternoon (14:00–18:00)
- Ferry + train back to Hiroshima
- 🚄 Shinkansen Hiroshima → **Shin-Osaka** (~2 hrs)
- **Haruka Express** from Shin-Osaka/Tennoji to **Kansai International Airport (KIX)** (~50 min, ¥1,800)

Evening
- ✈️ Fly out of KIX
- If late flight: Last meal at KIX — decent food options in the terminal

**Costs:** Transport (mostly JR Pass + Haruka ¥1,800) | Hiroshima ¥200 | Miyajima ¥1,400 | Food ¥3,000
**Booking:** JR Pass covers most trains. Haruka tickets buyable at station.
**Tips:** This day is TIGHT. If your flight is before 8 PM, skip Miyajima and just do Hiroshima + Peace Museum, then head to KIX with buffer time. Alternatively, do Hiroshima/Miyajima as a Day 12 swap with Himeji and keep Day 14 relaxed.

content:
Alternative Schedule (Recommended Swap)

If you want a less stressful final day:
- **Day 12:** Hiroshima + Miyajima (full day trip from Kyoto/Osaka)
- **Day 13:** Suzuka Circuit + Himeji Castle (morning Suzuka, afternoon Himeji on the way back)  
- **Day 14:** Relaxed Osaka morning, last shopping at **Super Autobacs Osaka** or **UpGarage Osaka**, fly out KIX

---

Packing Essentials for Car Enthusiast
- 📷 Camera + extra batteries (cold kills batteries)
- 🧤 Warm layers — late Feb is 3–10°C, colder at altitude/night
- 👟 Driving shoes (thin sole, good pedal feel) for Fun2Drive
- 🔌 USB-C charger, Japan uses Type A plugs (same as US!)
- 💴 Cash — Japan is still cash-heavy, especially at car meets, small restaurants, UpGarage
- 🪪 International Driving Permit + US license + passport copies
- 🎵 Initial D eurobeat playlist loaded on phone

Key Booking Timeline
| When | What |
|---|---|
| **4+ months ahead** | Flights, JR Pass purchase |
| **2–3 months ahead** | Fun2Drive (AE86 + RX-7), Ryokan, Omakase sushi |
| **1–2 months ahead** | Hotels, rental car (Gunma day), Fuji Speedway, Suzuka events |
| **2 weeks ahead** | Romancecar tickets, capsule hotel |
| **Walk-up** | All temples, Daikoku PA, UpGarage, Toyota Museum, Nissan Gallery |

Useful Apps
- **Google Maps** — Works perfectly in Japan, transit directions are flawless
- **Tabelog** — Japan's real restaurant review app (3.5+ is excellent)
- **Suica/Pasmo** on Apple Wallet — Tap to ride all trains
- **Google Translate** — Camera mode for menus
- **Navitime** — Better for driving navigation in Japan

---

*Last updated: Feb 2026 | Prices approximate, verify closer to trip | ¥ rates assume ~150 ¥/$*

content:
# Vex Memory System v2.0: A Next-Generation AI Memory Architecture

**Author:** Vex  
**Date:** February 13, 2026  
**Target Hardware:** Framework 12th gen i7, 32GB RAM, PostgreSQL available  

---

The current flat markdown file system (`MEMORY.md` + daily logs) works but is primitive. It's like having a filing cabinet when you need a brain. This design proposes a **hybrid graph-vector memory architecture** that combines the relationship understanding of knowledge graphs with the semantic power of embeddings, optimized for a single AI agent's long-term memory consolidation.

facts.subject: but
facts.source_context: but is primitive

emotional_markers.entity: having a filing cabinet when you need a brain
emotional_markers.context: like having a filing cabinet when you need a brain

content: **Core Philosophy:** Memory should be *associative* (like human memory), not just *searchable*. The system should understand that "Ethan mentioned X while discussing Y last Tuesday" is fundamentally different from "the latest update on X."

emotional_markers.entity: human memory), not just *searchable*
emotional_markers.context: like human memory), not just *searchable*

content: Memory System Architecture

```ascii
┌─────────────────────── VEX MEMORY SYSTEM v2.0 ────────────────────────┐
│                                                                        │
│  ┌─────────────────┐    ┌─────────────────┐    ┌─────────────────┐    │
│  │   RAW INPUTS    │    │  CONSOLIDATION  │    │  LONG-TERM GRAPH│    │
│  │                 │    │     ENGINE      │    │                 │    │
│  │ • Daily logs    │───▶│                 │───▶│ • Knowledge     │    │
│  │ • Conversations │    │ • Entity extract│    │   Graph         │    │
│  │ • Observations  │    │ • Relation map  │    │ • Vector index  │    │
│  │ • Decisions     │    │ • Temporal link │    │ • Temporal      │    │
│  └─────────────────┘    │ • Importance    │    │   chains        │    │
│                          │   scoring       │    └─────────────────┘    │
│  ┌─────────────────┐    │ • Forgetting    │                           │
│  │   RETRIEVAL     │◀───┤   curves        │                           │
│  │                 │    └─────────────────┘                           │
│  │ • Semantic      │                                                   │
│  │   similarity    │    ┌─────────────────┐                           │
│  │ • Graph walk    │    │   QUERY ENGINE  │                           │
│  │ • Temporal      │◀───│                 │                           │
│  │   reasoning     │    │ • Natural lang  │                           │
│  │ • Context       │    │ • Temporal      │                           │
│  │   assembly      │    │ • Associative   │                           │
│  └─────────────────┘    └─────────────────┘                           │
└────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```
Technology Stack Decisions

Graph Database: PostgreSQL + Apache AGE
**Why not Neo4j?**
- AGE integrates with existing PostgreSQL (already available)
- Lower memory footprint for single-node deployment
- SQL familiarity for debugging and administration
- Can co-locate with vector data in same database
- No separate service to maintain

Embedding Model: nomic-embed-text-v1.5
**Why not all-MiniLM-L6-v2?**
- 1.2% better accuracy vs slight speed penalty
- Better long-context understanding (8192 tokens)
- More robust to domain shifts
- Runs well on 32GB RAM system
- Accuracy matters more than speed for memory retrieval

Vector Store: pgvector (PostgreSQL Extension)
**Why not ChromaDB/Qdrant?**
- Single database for graph + vectors = simpler ops
- ACID transactions across memory operations
- No data consistency issues between stores
- PostgreSQL's reliability and tooling ecosystem
- Easier backup and recovery strategy

Memory Consolidation Engine: Custom Python Service
**Why custom?**
- Existing solutions (Mem0, Zep, MemGPT) either too complex or too simple
- Need specific temporal reasoning and forgetting curves
- Want full control over consolidation logic
- Integration with OpenClaw ecosystem requirements

---
Memory Types and Data Model

```sql
-- Core memory nodes in the graph
CREATE TYPE memory_type AS ENUM (
    'episodic',    -- Specific events: "Ethan said X at time Y"
    'semantic',    -- Facts: "Ethan prefers Python over JavaScript"
    'procedural',  -- How-tos: "To deploy project X, do Y"
    'emotional'    -- Reactions: "Ethan was frustrated with deployment issues"
);

-- Main memory nodes table
CREATE TABLE memory_nodes (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
    type memory_type NOT NULL,
    content TEXT NOT NULL,
    embedding vector(768), -- nomic-embed output
    
    -- Temporal information
    created_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE NOT NULL,
    event_time TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE, -- when the remembered event happened
    last_accessed TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NOW(),
    
    -- Importance and decay
    importance_score FLOAT DEFAULT 0.5, -- 0.0 to 1.0
    access_count INTEGER DEFAULT 0,
    decay_factor FLOAT DEFAULT 1.0, -- decreases over time
    
    -- Metadata
    source TEXT, -- 'conversation', 'observation', 'decision', etc.
    entities JSONB, -- extracted entities
    context_id UUID, -- reference to conversation/session
    
    CONSTRAINT importance_score_range CHECK (importance_score BETWEEN 0.0 AND 1.0),
    CONSTRAINT decay_factor_range CHECK (decay_factor BETWEEN 0.0 AND 1.0)
);

CREATE TABLE entities (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
    name TEXT NOT NULL,
    type TEXT NOT NULL, -- 'person', 'project', 'concept', 'location', etc.
    canonical_name TEXT, -- standardized form
    aliases TEXT[], -- alternative names

);

-- Link entities to memory nodes
CREATE TABLE memory_entity_mentions (
    memory_id UUID REFERENCES memory_nodes(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    entity_id UUID REFERENCES entities(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    mention_context TEXT, -- the specific text that mentioned this entity
    PRIMARY KEY (memory_id, entity_id)

class MemoryConsolidator:
    def __init__(self):
        self.graph_db = AGEConnection()
        self.vector_db = PgVectorConnection()
        self.embedding_model = NomicEmbedModel()
    
    async def consolidate_daily_memories(self, target_date: date):
        """Main consolidation pipeline - like human sleep memory processing"""
        
        # 1. Extract entities and relations from raw daily logs
        raw_memories = await self.load_daily_logs(target_date)
        structured_memories = await self.structure_raw_memories(raw_memories)
        
        # 2. Identify new entities and update existing ones
        await self.update_entity_graph(structured_memories)
        
        # 3. Create memory nodes with importance scoring
        memory_nodes = await self.create_memory_nodes(structured_memories)
        
        # 4. Find relationships between memories
        await self.build_relationship_graph(memory_nodes)
        
        # 5. Apply forgetting curves to older memories
        await self.apply_decay_functions()
        
        # 6. Optimize graph structure (merge similar nodes, prune weak connections)
        await self.optimize_graph_structure()

content: Importance Scoring Algorithm

```python
def calculate_importance_score(memory: MemoryNode) -> float:
    """Multi-factor importance scoring"""
    
    # Base factors
    recency_factor = calculate_recency_bonus(memory.created_at)
    entity_importance = sum(e.importance_score for e in memory.entities) / len(memory.entities)
    content_novelty = calculate_content_novelty(memory.content)
    
    # Interaction factors
    access_frequency = min(memory.access_count / 10.0, 1.0)  # cap at 1.0
    relationship_strength = calculate_avg_relationship_weight(memory.id)
    
    # Type-specific modifiers
    type_modifier = {
        'episodic': 0.8,    # events decay faster than facts
        'semantic': 1.2,    # facts are more persistently important
        'procedural': 1.0,  # how-tos have medium persistence
        'emotional': 0.9    # emotions are important but fade
    }[memory.type]
    
    # Combine factors
    base_score = (
        0.3 * recency_factor +
        0.25 * entity_importance +
        0.2 * content_novelty +
        0.15 * access_frequency +
        0.1 * relationship_strength
    )
    
    return min(base_score * type_modifier, 1.0)
```

content: Forgetting Curves Implementation

```python
def apply_forgetting_curve(memory: MemoryNode, days_since_creation: int) -> float:
    """Ebbinghaus-inspired forgetting curve with modern tweaks"""
    
    # Base forgetting curve: retention = e^(-t/S)
    # Where S is the stability (how long the memory lasts)
    
    stability = calculate_stability(memory)
    base_retention = math.exp(-days_since_creation / stability)
    
    # Modifiers that fight forgetting:
    access_boost = 1.0 + (memory.access_count * 0.1)  # accessed memories stick
    importance_boost = 1.0 + (memory.importance_score * 0.5)  # important things stick
    relationship_boost = 1.0 + (memory.relationship_count * 0.05)  # connected memories stick
    
    # Apply modifiers
    retention_rate = min(base_retention * access_boost * importance_boost * relationship_boost, 1.0)
    
    return retention_rate

content: Query Engine and Retrieval
Natural Language Query Processing

```python
class MemoryQueryEngine:
    def __init__(self):
        self.graph_db = AGEConnection()
        self.embedding_model = NomicEmbedModel()
        self.temporal_parser = TemporalParser()
    
    async def query(self, natural_query: str, context: QueryContext = None) -> MemoryResponse:
        """Main query interface - handles natural language memory questions"""
        
        # Parse query for different types of information needs
        query_intent = await self.parse_query_intent(natural_query)
        
        if query_intent.type == 'temporal':
            return await self.temporal_query(query_intent)
        elif query_intent.type == 'semantic':
            return await self.semantic_query(query_intent)
        elif query_intent.type == 'associative':
            return await self.associative_query(query_intent)
        elif query_intent.type == 'procedural':
            return await self.procedural_query(query_intent)
        else:
            # Hybrid approach - combine multiple strategies
            return await self.hybrid_query(query_intent)
    
    async def temporal_query(self, intent: QueryIntent) -> MemoryResponse:
        """Handle time-based queries: 'What did Ethan say about X last week?'"""
        
        time_range = self.temporal_parser.parse(intent.temporal_expression)
        entity_filters = intent.entities
        
        # Graph query for memories in time range mentioning entities
        cypher_query = """
        MATCH (m:MemoryNode)-[:MENTIONS]->(e:Entity)
        WHERE e.name IN $entities
        AND m.event_time >= $start_time
        AND m.event_time <= $end_time
        RETURN m, e
        ORDER BY m.event_time DESC, m.importance_score DESC
        LIMIT $limit
        """
        
        results = await self.graph_db.execute(cypher_query, {
            'entities': entity_filters,
            'start_time': time_range.start,
            'end_time': time_range.end,
            'limit': 10
        })
        
        return self.assemble_response(results, intent)
    
    async def semantic_query(self, intent: QueryIntent) -> MemoryResponse:
        """Handle similarity-based queries: 'What do I know about Python?'"""
        
        query_embedding = await self.embedding_model.encode(intent.content)
        
        # Vector similarity search
        sql_query = """
        SELECT m.*, m.embedding <=> $query_vector as distance
        FROM memory_nodes m
        WHERE m.type = ANY($memory_types)
        ORDER BY m.embedding <=> $query_vector
        LIMIT $limit
        """
        
        results = await self.vector_db.execute(sql_query, {
            'query_vector': query_embedding,
            'memory_types': intent.memory_types or ['semantic', 'procedural'],
            'limit': 10
        })
        
        return self.assemble_response(results, intent)
    
    async def associative_query(self, intent: QueryIntent) -> MemoryResponse:
        """Handle relationship-based queries: 'What's connected to project X?'"""
        
        # Graph walk to find related concepts
        cypher_query = """
        MATCH (start:MemoryNode)-[:MENTIONS]->(e:Entity {name: $entity_name})
        MATCH (start)-[r:RELATION*1..3]-(related:MemoryNode)
        WHERE r.weight > $min_weight
        RETURN start, related, r
        ORDER BY r.weight DESC, related.importance_score DESC
        LIMIT $limit
        """
        
        results = await self.graph_db.execute(cypher_query, {
            'entity_name': intent.primary_entity,
            'min_weight': 0.3,
            'limit': 15
        })
        
        return self.assemble_response(results, intent)
```
Context Assembly for LLM

```python
async def assemble_context_for_conversation(
    self, 
    current_message: str,
    conversation_history: List[str],
    max_tokens: int = 4000
) -> ContextBundle:
    """Intelligently assemble relevant context for the current conversation"""
    
    # 1. Immediate context - recent conversation
    immediate_context = conversation_history[-10:]  # last 10 messages
    
    # 2. Semantic relevance - what's this conversation about?
    conversation_embedding = await self.embedding_model.encode(
        " ".join([current_message] + immediate_context)
    )
    
    semantic_memories = await self.vector_search(
        conversation_embedding,
        limit=20,
        min_score=0.7
    )
    
    # 3. Entity-based relevance - who/what are we talking about?
    entities_mentioned = await self.extract_entities(current_message)
    entity_memories = await self.get_entity_related_memories(entities_mentioned)
    
    # 4. Temporal relevance - recent important memories
    recent_memories = await self.get_recent_important_memories(days=7, limit=10)
    
    # 5. Procedural relevance - if they're asking how to do something
    if self.is_procedural_query(current_message):
        procedural_memories = await self.get_procedural_memories(current_message)
    else:
        procedural_memories = []
    
    # 6. Combine and rank by composite relevance score
    all_candidate_memories = (
        semantic_memories + entity_memories + recent_memories + procedural_memories
    )
    
    # Remove duplicates and rank
    unique_memories = self.deduplicate_memories(all_candidate_memories)
    ranked_memories = self.rank_by_relevance(unique_memories, current_message)
    
    # 7. Assemble context within token budget
    return self.build_context_bundle(
        immediate_context=immediate_context,
        memories=ranked_memories,
        max_tokens=max_tokens
    )

content: Edge Cases and Conflict Resolution

Memory Conflicts
```python
class MemoryConflictResolver:
    async def handle_conflicting_memories(self, new_memory: MemoryNode, existing_memories: List[MemoryNode]):
        """What to do when memories contradict each other"""
        
        for existing in existing_memories:
            conflict_type = self.detect_conflict_type(new_memory, existing)
            
            if conflict_type == 'factual_contradiction':
                # Example: "Ethan likes Python" vs "Ethan hates Python"
                await self.resolve_factual_conflict(new_memory, existing)
                
            elif conflict_type == 'temporal_inconsistency':
                # Example: Two events can't both be "last Tuesday"
                await self.resolve_temporal_conflict(new_memory, existing)
                
            elif conflict_type == 'preference_evolution':
                # Example: Ethan's opinion on something changed
                await self.create_preference_timeline(new_memory, existing)
    
    async def resolve_factual_conflict(self, new_memory: MemoryNode, old_memory: MemoryNode):
        """Handle contradictory facts"""
        
        # Check recency - newer information generally wins
        if new_memory.event_time > old_memory.event_time:
            # Mark old memory as potentially outdated
            await self.add_relation(old_memory, new_memory, 'contradicts', confidence=0.8)
            
            # Reduce importance of old memory but don't delete it
            old_memory.importance_score *= 0.7
            old_memory.decay_factor *= 0.8
            
            # Boost importance of new memory
            new_memory.importance_score = min(new_memory.importance_score * 1.2, 1.0)
        
        # Create explicit contradiction relationship
        await self.create_contradiction_node(new_memory, old_memory)
```
Memory Pollution Prevention
Migration Plan from Current System

Phase 1: Parallel System (Weeks 1-2)
1. **Setup Infrastructure**
   - Install PostgreSQL extensions (AGE, pgvector)
   - Deploy nomic-embed model locally
   - Create database schema
   - Build basic consolidation service

2. **Historical Data Import**
   - Parse existing `MEMORY.md` into structured memories
   - Extract entities and relationships using LLM
   - Import daily logs from `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` files
   - Run initial consolidation process

Phase 2: Feature Development (Weeks 3-4)
1. **Query Engine**
   - Implement natural language query parsing
   - Build retrieval algorithms (semantic, temporal, associative)
   - Create context assembly pipeline
   - Add conflict resolution logic

2. **Integration Points**
   - Hook into existing OpenClaw heartbeat system
   - Connect to current memory reading workflow
   - Create API endpoints for memory queries
   - Build monitoring and debugging tools

Phase 3: Gradual Migration (Weeks 5-6)
1. **Hybrid Operation**
   - Run both old and new systems in parallel
   - Compare query results for accuracy
   - Gradually shift query load to new system
   - Keep old system as fallback

2. **Quality Validation**
   - A/B test memory retrieval quality
   - Validate entity extraction accuracy
   - Fine-tune importance scoring algorithms
   - Optimize forgetting curves

Phase 4: Full Cutover (Week 7)
1. **Complete Migration**
   - Disable old flat file queries
   - Archive old markdown files
   - Make new system primary
   - Remove old code paths

Resource Requirements and Performance

Hardware Utilization
- **RAM:** ~12-16GB for full system (leaves 16GB+ for other tasks)
  - PostgreSQL + extensions: ~4GB
  - nomic-embed model: ~2GB
  - Vector indices: ~4-6GB (scales with memory volume)
  - Consolidation service: ~2-4GB during processing

- **Storage:** ~5-10GB for first year of operation
  - Graph data: ~2-3GB
  - Vector embeddings: ~2-4GB
  - Indices and metadata: ~1-3GB

- **CPU:** Minimal during normal operation, intensive during consolidation
  - Query processing: <100ms for most queries
  - Daily consolidation: ~30-60 minutes processing time
  - Embedding generation: ~10-50ms per memory

Performance Targets
- **Query Latency:** <200ms for semantic queries, <100ms for graph queries
- **Memory Capacity:** Support 10,000+ memories with sub-second retrieval
- **Consolidation Time:** Complete daily processing in <1 hour
- **Context Assembly:** <500ms to build conversation context

- **Practical Design:** Optimized for single AI agent on consumer hardware
